developer_response:
Hello Chee,

We are sorry you've had this negative experience but there is a lot of information in this review that conflicts with verifiable facts, as follows:

Point 1. It works better with a good camera and better light, but it also works in non ideal light conditions:
Independent source: many user screenshots from Steam like this one : http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=564196486
or this one:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=551672290
or you can find more by browsing the screenshots section.

Tracking got even better when we switched to the ULSee tracker in Spring 2015. It is true, the users who optimise their capture space get far better results than the ones who don't, but the program does work even in non ideal conditions.

Point 2. The crowdfunding campaign for FaceRig ended in February 2014, and the program was on Steam in Early Access available to the public on August 29 2014, (was available to all the backers 24 hours before, on 28'th of August 2014).  
That's just 7 months, not years, and it matches the promise we had made in the crowdfunding campaign. In those seven months  we've communicated on Facebook and email and we also had 7 official updates on Indiegogo (1 update per month). Then as the months went on we made them less frequent ( every two months, then 3 months, 6 months), and this was done at the requests of some of our backers because they simply got their news from the website or Steam. 
Independent source: The Indiegogo website: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/facerig#/updates

3. Occasional crashes might have happened during the course of development, as we do work with hardware and software not typically used in game development ( webcams and virtualdrivers) , but they were usually corrected if a bug report was correctly filled.

4. Please reach out to us on info[at]facerig[dot]com and please point out the emails or support thread so we follow up on the status of the rude comments. 
The workshop does have quite a few avatars already, both 2d and 3d. 
We offer art support as our time allows (we are a small team after all) for issues that are specific to importing a 3D asset in Facerig, but not general art support for aspiring 3D modellers /animators who are just learning how to use a 3D modelling package (although we wish it was possible in an ideal world, the truth is in the real world we simply do not have the time and resources to also teach people how to use 3DS Max and Maya, that is not the purpose of our art team, we need to let you know about aspects specific to FaceRig).

5. No Man's Sky has a Steam overall rating of 32%. FaceRig has 84%. 
They are hardly similar in regard to public reception. I understand that your personal opinion is different, but in reality they are simply not the same.  Source: Steam Store Ratings.

Also:We did almost no traditional marketing for FaceRig, its was mostly organic growth, via word of mouth, mainly people using it on Steam, Twitch  and YouTube. We've always stated that tongue control on the regular webcam version is done via puppeteering  controls, not tracking, and that you need depth sensors for reliable tongue tracking.


Best regards,
The FaceRig Team.

Before I start, let me tell you that Ange Katrina (nijisanji) is the highest tier of Vtuber and no one can ever reach her angelic status. That said, FaceRig, AKA "How to bank on the Vtuber Boom", is a program to turn yourself into an anime girl, boy, fairy, dog,  furry, herr wolf, Or a 6foot3 african american with a 12 incher.

if you thought that Joke was inappropriate, wait until you see my draft

Anyway, if you‚Äôre looking for FaceRig, then you probably already know what it is and what it does. If you suffer from dementia or something, here‚Äôs a refresher. It takes a camera input, does some face tracking magic to it, put it into a 3D Model/Live2D avatar, and output it as a video/stream. There‚Äôs other software that can do this, but Considering how old FaceRig is, I‚Äôd consider it to be the easiest, most feature rich, and most accessible (the fact that It has a community constantly uploading models also helps) compared to other options (unless you have an entire company developing their own version of course). That being said, you do need the Live2D module DLC to use about 99% of the community uploaded stuff, and I‚Äôm pretty sure 99% of the time, that‚Äôs what you‚Äôre going to use this for.
All resource and documentation can be searched online. Use it to turn whatever 2d Fantasy you‚Äôre dreaming every night. Use a voice changer if you want to add to the effect. You should preferably buy it on discount, although it‚Äôs pretty reasonably priced nonetheless. Cheers.

Nice software, but if you want to use it to stream games it may not be for you via Steam.  Steam does not let you use steam on 2 computers at the same time, so if you game on 1 computer and capture and stream via OBS on another you can not use this software on the 2nd computer.  Since it is high CPU usage, doing it on the gaming rig will greatly reduce your gaming experience.  FYI on a I7-3770 with 16gb memory cpu usage of the program alone is 15%.

After playing around with this for a few hours and deemed unfit for a refund, I decided it at least deserves a review.

Looking at this purely as a streaming tool, I find it to be hot garbage. At least, the 3dDmodels and how inaccessible it is to use custom models, unless you have a vast amount of experience in 3D modelling, and even that's not going to be a walk in the park. If you're looking for commissions, you're looking at hundreds of dollars, potentially over a thousand for a full setup. On top of that, the 3D models are simply fairly lazy and un-creative, none of them really being a remotely worthy replacement or addition to a webcam for streaming.

On to the most unfortunate things about the actual program, I have no issue with Direct 11 games but for whatever reason, you're stuck with Direct 9 otherwise it simply will not launch. The audio inputs and outputs it adds are reported by a vast amount of users as completely messing up the audio on their system. Fortunately, I didn't have enough hours with the experience where it left a turd stain on my computer as a goodbye present but unfortunately, too many to negate a potential refund, but I can't say I got my money's worth.

The tracking is fairly poor, but the worst part is the mouth and the "talking" animation. As reported by others, if you've got a beard or glasses, good luck getting an accurate representation. While for your eyesight you can always put on automatic blinking, I've not found a very good system to work with the lip tracking, the audio lip sync was worthless and just didn't work well enough to consider it an option. It really didn't seem to capture your expressions at all, maybe at a 25% effort was all it could really muster. 

Overall, if you're looking to stream, you're going to want to look into the 2D DLC because the 3D is hardly worth the effort., The avatars really don't look very good and the tracking and syncing will get you maybe a couple of hours worth of entertainment. Either way, unless you know something about 3D modelling or have a lot of money to spare on commissions, or you really don't care too much about customising a decent looking avatar, I'd avoid this. The ability to take your webcam and make it into a 2d/3d model animation seems so plausible nowadays, but we're not there yet.

With the l2d dlc you can stream as a cute anime girl instead of your greasy, ugly self.

Mind you, if you decide to go commercial [ or if you decide to make YouTube videos on a monetized channel, you will have to purchase extended license once you reach a certain amount of subscribers ].

This software can map head-movements and some facial expressions from a real time input (eg webcam) to an avatar. The result can for an example be redirected to the video input of a zoom meeting. Audio can also be modified (eg change your voice to robot sound) and some additional changes like background and text.
The avatar-designs are gorgeous, the software has a nice interface and quite some functionality. It is definitely worth the 15 bucks I was charged.
But: I think the mapping from real face to avatar could be done much better as of today (year 2020). It looks like the AI-Tech is on a level like 5 years old.

You know, back when FaceRig came out in 2015, I found it to be pretty neat and cool, and somewhat functioned as intended. However, as of my most recent experience, it has brought me great shame and disappointment; sheer anger even.  

When I installed and booted up this program I was greeted with a 17 step setup that required me to install 3 separate 3rd party programs to finish the setup, one of which completely tourso-grinded my audio drivers, and the other two turned my computer into the equivalent to that of a shitty single slice toaster. Beyond all of that, the software wouldn't even start when I tried to boot it through their launcher; so I did what any normal person would do in this situation, uninstall the software. But here's the problem, what about the other 3 pieces of shit programs that had to be installed just for fancy shmancy facial recognition software, that didn‚Äôt make it work run off to? It wasn't uninstalled that's for sure. And why the fuck does my computer still run like hot trash? that's a good question, task manager doesn't seem to know, guess I'll just fuck myself. 

I remember when I first used this program back in 2015, the facial recognition wasn‚Äôt the best, and as far as I‚Äôve seen to date, there hasn‚Äôt been too many improvements, if any. Every now and then the avatar will appear to have a lazy eye if the users eyes aren‚Äôt open enough, and sometimes appear to be having a stroke, or that 1000 mile stare. Unless the user has a pristine face, with over exaggerated features, I think the avatars would work just fine. But anything other than that, the program might have a serious problem with it. Seems kinda face-ist if you ask me. 

Now in the year 2020, I never thought I would see pictures load from the top down; from what felt like a 5 minute google search. After I installed and then uninstalled this piece of shit software, I was greeted with the nostalgic feeling of the early 2000's. I honestly wouldn't be surprised if it made me install some sort of malware, or even started using my computer to mine crypto, because that's what it felt like. one hard reset on my computer that took longer than it should have seemed to fix my problem of crippling processing speeds, it was almost like my computer went to get lobotomized, but ended up getting sodomized instead. The sheer inconvenience of a facial recognition software pegging my computer in every way possible, not doing what was promised, had truly invigorated me to make this review. 

Words don't describe how I feel about this program, I‚Äôd have to be some nihilistic fuck freak that suffered from some serious head trauma to even enjoy this program. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend this program if it was the last facial recognition software on earth, especially in the state that it's in. The fact that it isn't compatible with pre-installed Realteck audio drivers, makes me question what the fuck went wrong in the development of this program. Seriously it's facial recognition software, not a god damn soundboard. What the fuck does FaceRig need to transmit audio for, and why do I need to install shitty 3rd party software for it anyway, why couldn't the audio drivers come with the program? Again, why does it even need the audio drivers? Something here doesn‚Äôt seem to be adding up, but that might just be me.

Another thing that really bothers me is the lack of a community workshop, something that this type of software should have, and would benefit from having; a feature that should have been implemented a long time ago. It would have something more to offer the community, but instead it‚Äôs a dollar or more for a pack of characters, if not one avatar. doesn't seem right to me given the price of the base program. On top of the base program there‚Äôs the pro and studio versions, and reading the description for the pro version alone, makes me feel like my bottom end is being reamed for all it's worth; giving no technical advancements/improvements in terms of the base program, and as far as I'm aware it's for people that are ‚Äúmaking profit‚Äù off of the classic version, or are using it for commercial use. if someone‚Äôs making more than $500 a month while using the classic software, they must now spend part of their next paycheck on their knees to face rig, and then on some licensing that doesn‚Äôt seem to come along with it. Also as far as I'm aware - as the description doesn't say anything about it - the DLC avatars don't come with the pro software, so there‚Äôs more cock sucking action that may need to be commenced, just to add some avatars to the users arsenal. As if they haven‚Äôt spent enough.

Now I can vaguely understand the reasoning behind not having a community workshop for the program, due to people making avatars of licensed characters from movies and what not, perhaps something that could get the company into trouble, or maybe even hinder the reputation, but there's a bunch of other products out there that have a community workshop, and as far as I'm aware they haven't gotten into any serious shenanigans. Looking at something like VR chat, it may not be a facial recognition software, but there‚Äôs a lot of impressive avatars made by the community that could get someone into a lot of trouble. Even with that, I‚Äôm sure implementing some sort of filter, or verification system, would be better than not having any community involvement at all, perhaps having some sort of event for who can make the best avatar, would be going in a step in the right direction, in terms of building a bigger community. 

I think that this program still has a long way to go, and hasn‚Äôt really changed a whole lot since it‚Äôs release, maybe a few patches that helped with facial recognition, but I personally don‚Äôt see much of an improvement. I can say with certainty that FaceRig will not be the end all be all in terms of facial recognition software that turns people into an avatar. I can see some other company coming in, and offering more to the table then FaceRig has currently. I don‚Äôt fully agree with the price, or  the terms of HoloTech, it seems to me like they‚Äôre trying to milk their program for all it‚Äôs worth. I don‚Äôt see a problem with asking for more with the Pro versions, but I think that when someone is making at least $500 just for using FaceRig, even though it may have little to nothing to do with that money is a little bit of a stretch, and asking for more than 10% of that for the pro version is kinda bullshit. But that‚Äôs just business.

TLDR; I think this program is a steaming pile of dogshit, that needs some sort of community workshop/involvement, better facial recognition technology, better price for what you get and not have mandatory third party software that bricks your computer.

Unless someone has access to a time machine that goes back to when FaceRig first came out, and the technology had that wow factor. I cannot recommend this software to anyone, for any reason at all. If I could refund this I 100% would, but I‚Äôm afraid I‚Äôm more than a few years past the expiry on that one.

Things to keep in mind before buying.

1.) Face rigs does not work well for those with beards. If your lips are covered by a beard it will not function as intended.

2.) glasses . Like the beard would also get in the way  with the program

3.) when you calibrate made sure that your face is  neutral for best effect. 

4.) if you have  back ground sound like fans it will trigger lip movement even when you are not speaking. go into sound devices and look for facerig virtual mic turn that down.Doing so in program isn't always  accurate. I had to turn it down in  sound devices  for mine to stop that. Turning it down in the program did not work even when I set it to almost muted.

First I want to start off with saying I contacted the Dev's via Twitter as I was curious about a Dragon model, and much to my surprise in under nine minutes I received a reply. Looking through the discussion page here on steam, I am impressed as this is a level of Customer care you cannot find anywhere. But enough about that, you are here wondering what I think about the program, so:

Upon first launch of the program I did need to wait for a rather short period of time as 21 other programs were needed. Do not let this scare you, as they are rather small, and things that cannot be added through stream. I ran this program on my laptop, so I was very pleased to see it did auto detection through the included web cam. On less thing for me to jack around with. There was a slight issue with the models not looking right, however using the built in Calibration, and everything is fine.

The UI is rather clean, and rather intuitive, so you are not having to waste countless hours with google searches and asking how to get it to run, and the ability to take pictures and make videos from the program it's self is very nice. There is even a option to control the lip syncing, and if you are like me; you can change pitch and tone of the voice to match the model you want to use again within the program it's self.

my only  complaint which is a rather small one is that when downloaded and opening the program, it switches my audio output to the program, which in turn cancels out all other audio from my computer. However this took a whole two seconds to fix, however this cancels out my live sampling. 

But other then that, if I can having this program up and running and doing videos in under then minutes then anyone can. Thank you to the Dev's for the work they put into this.

In 2015, this seemed like some new interesting software. The price tag on this should have been lowered to $5 by now and here is why:

1) The lack of software updates and improvements makes it feel like the lead developers abandoned it. Only a few new models are added every few months, but no significant program improvements are made. I bought this program a couple years ago because I thought it was really cool and believed the developers' intent on future implementations like hand recognition. That obviously hasn't happened yet. 

2) Face-tracking is still mediocre. If you have any facial obstructions, such as long hair, glasses, etc., the program won't recognize you. Half the time, it seems like the facial tracking overexaggerates expressions or outright fails to accurately capture simple facial expressions like winking. 

3) The process of adding your own non-Live2D model is daunting if not near impossible. If you think adding your own VRChat avatar is a pain in the ass, you don't even know the horror show behind adding a 3D character in FaceRig. I wanted to add some of my own models in, but it just didn't seem worth the effort considering reason #2 and the practical uses of this software. Plus, their [url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B9A2HzJCWwFWYnN6SFRPbW1mRWM/view]guide[/url] is the only actual information they provide apart from a video, but neither of those are helpful.

4) Even though there are other characters that can be downloaded from the Steam Workshop, around 70% of them are Live2D anime characters. I have nothing against 2D or anime characters, but it only points out the disparaging lack of 3D model content.

5) Configuration is irritating because it is required every time before rendering the models and the settings don't actually save. 

I would have recommended this when I first bought it, but I recant that notion. The actual application usage is extremely limited, so wait until a price drop before buying this.

[u]EDIT: January 1, 2020[/u]

A late change in my review, but if you want to stream with this software, you have to pay even more money to essentially get a license that allows you to use this software in any videos or streaming sites with monetization. Their greed only proves this software was just a marketing endeavor.

Also, same code and UI over the past 3+ years. Normally, software like this goes through an overhaul, but this one hasn't. Hilariously enough, the devs wonder why nobody is making any 3D content when the process is so extensive.

The motion capture works very well, but is limited - if you move to quickly or get too close to the edge of the field of view, it'll stop. Sometimes the tracking will freeze and I'll have to stop and re-start it, but there's no alert for it, so I have to keep an eye on it. The wide array of avatars is excellent, and the customization is superb, but the props are very limited.... and unusual. The props don't have much customization other than size and position. Like... a pair of green glasses can't have the color changed to something else (which is sad b/c green is terrible for green screen chroma key backgrounds)

Installation through STEAM is simple, it works well with OBS, but it'll take some tinkering to set it up properly. 

Overall, I highly recommend & look forward to more DLC and updates.

The performance of this software is terrible. Absolutely abysmal.  It tracks terribly, it syncs audio and video terribly, and it captures facial expressions terribly.  Only the most rudimentary facial expressions are captured. My eyes move a bit, my eyebrows move unreliably, my mouth -sort of- opens and closes. How much it opens or closes is up to who knows what. Some avatars constantly twitch their eyebrows, despite me maintaining a neutral expression, yet respond improperly to the movement of my eyebrows should I actually move them.  To extend my avatar's tongue I have to hit keyboard combinations. The muscles in my face which capture my expression are not simulated. My avatar is basically neutral, happy, or slightly irritated, or making an intense expression with its eyebrows. That's it. Eye tracking is unreliable, exports of recordings distort audio and de-sync it with video by up to 10 seconds.

Yes I calibrated. Yes I looked at the advanced settings thoroughly.

TL;DR: Very tough to recommend with long bangs, long facial hair, or narrow eyes. However it's certainly usable even with those.

We recommend this with some caveats. It actually tracks fairly good with a 1080p camera. The eyes look fantastic even with semi long eyelashes and the blink tracking works pretty darn well. The head tracking is also pretty fantastic, however tilting your head forward or back can also affect how other parts of the face are scanned for 2D avatars. Looking up might make your character open it's mouth for instance. Though the program is pretty flexible with it's advanced tracking configuration. So messing around with that can make it a lot less noticeable for 3D avatars. Long bangs can get in the way of eyebrow tracking, so it's advised to tie hair back or trim bangs. Mustache hair can get in the way of mouth tracking, so shape it up or pair it down. Narrow eyes make it a tad harder for it to notice eye movements, but only marginally so.

For the best experience we highly recommend trying to customize as much as you can yourself after you set the "auto configure". Each person we used had a different face and required some settings to be changed. Also, remember that you can save auto tracking configurations to be used later. However, note that some avatars work better with different configurations. For instance, some 2D avatars don't use a lot of the body movements, but the 3D avatars do. 

Hand tracking and tongue tracking is also possible with the IR Real Sense intel camera, but we have yet to get one. Will update review once we manage to pick one up.

why is facerig blank in obs? I no longer know how

please helpme
developer_response:
Hello. It could be either of two reasons. First one, which I don't think is the case, is when the FaceRig Virtual Camera driver is missing (this causes the Virtual Camera to not appear as a source in OBS). The second one, which I think matches your issue, is the fact that you have to toggle ON the Broadcast option in FaceRig (from the bar of the UI).

I strongly suggest you start a thread on our Steam forums whenever you encounter an issue. It's easier for both of us that way.

I'm gonna have to review this one from a largely personal perspective. But I'll do my best to be a tad "objective" as well.

   First of all, I'm an artistic type, so I may have, erm...uses for this. Maybe. Not sure yet. So I'm eyeing up the "Pro Upgrade", which makes the whole package a tad more expensive, but is clearly of no use to anyone who just wants to amuse themselves and/or their friends. So is fifteen bucks a good buy if that's all you're looking to do with it: have a little fun? Sure, I'd say so. Possibly depends on how easily amused you are, and how many hours you think you'll get out of it all. Your money, your call.

   Second up, tech stuff. Hmmm...well, I have a pretty decent gaming laptop (HP Omen), and an at least passable webcam, and I've found the lip-syncing on this software to be...well, let's just say "inconsistent". I definitely seem to encounter "lag" issues here and there, but in all fairness, those of you with uber-rigs may not have the same problems. I'd probably advise reading other reviews to deduce this specs-specific information for yourself (Lord knows I'm no expert in that area, hence why I've kept my own information minimal).

   I've certainly managed some magical [i]moments[/i] here and there, and some of the characters are fantastically expressive, but...they all seem to have their definite limitations, i.e. some look good when shouting while others barely move their mouths, making them fit for little more than mumbling. I certainly haven't found a character that I would describe as having a terribly broad "emotional range". Again...depends what you're looking to use 'em for.

   Short version: a decent if unexceptional piece of "gimmick" software, with possible applications for those of us with more product-oriented goals in mind. I'd certainly recommend you have reasonably decent gear though, as I suspect this wouldn't run well on a "toaster". One thing I will give a very definite shout-out to: the character designs are by-and-largely fabulous, and you do get a reasonable variety of them with the basic version; though as with most things of this nature, you'll have to look to DLC and Workshop items to widen your options. And there does seem to be an absolute [i]shedload[/i] of free Workshop stuff, so that's a definite plus, though I can't yet personally vouch for how well any of these work.

   Oh, and one final warning: be patient when first installing. It took me quite a bit of trial-and-error to get the damn thing to [i]launch[/i], never mind get the best results out of my webcam, mic, etc. Don't expect to just plug-and-play, even if you're only in it for the fun. But fun you may well have, once you get the hang of it all.

   Verdict: 7.5/10.

(PS If you enjoyed this review, feel free to check out my two Curator pages: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9284586-ReviewsJustfortheHELLofit/
http://store.steampowered.com/curator/10868048-Truly-Horrible-Horror-Games/?appid=398210
Cheers!)

Update: 8/14/2019
This program is still a great one to use but I need to warn people of a little bug with the installation and using this program.  Sometimes it will default your audio output or camera device to its virtual version voiding your sound or ability to use your camera.  There is a quick and easy fix to this by just switching your default audio or camera from Facerig's virtual settings to your computer's default. I'm not very good at explaining how to do this but their are many videos and how-to guides on how to do this online.  If anyone wants me to make a video on how, I might.

My computer is a much better computer now and runs this pretty well. No need to uninstall to get the defaults to work again, just for your information. :) Hope this helps.

This is the most fun I've had with my PC since the invention of porn sites. It really, REALLY works like it's supposed to, and it's quite shocking when you launch it for the first time and realize it can almost flawlessy track your face. I tried a bunch of webcams, including an old Microsoft cam that is like 320x240 and has the picture quality of a 2001 smartphone - and it works fine, it almost feels like it doesn't really care about the picture quality. It doesn't even care about the position of your head that much - it can auto-calibrate and read your face movements AT AN ANGLE... almost feels like magic. And it's cheap, too! And it has tons of avatars to choose from! And you can also use your own! Very useful tool if you want to mess around with your friends on skype or discord. Also useful if you want to be a vlogger but are too shy to be on camera. I love this thing.

I cannot get the software to launch on Windows due to a code displaying c0000135
developer_response:
Hello, that error code points to the possibility of the redistributables not being installed correctly. What you have to do is go to Steam\steamapps\common\FaceRig\_CommonRedist\vcredist and install all of the redistributables found there. Alternatively, the path might also be just Steam\steamapps\common\Steamworks Shared\_CommonRedist\vcredist. Either way, follow that path and install the redistributables. 

As a side note, in the future, we encourage you to start a thread on our Steam forums for when you encounter errors, crashes, freezes or any technical problems with FaceRig, since we always respond to and find solutions for them.

review: I thought this software would be good but when I tried to use it during a stream its FPS dropped so bad to the point where its unusable. Face tracking isnt that great either.
developer_response:
Hi, for the tracker to properly work, you have to have enough light in your room so that your face will be clearly visible. As for the FPS drop, that might happen if you use both FaceRig and the other game with high settings; adding FaceRig to your streaming configuration (stream software + game) will add some CPU/GPU load. Face tracking and high quality rendering come with the CPU and GPU resource cost, so if you are running a game at high quality graphics option, you may have frame drops.

There are some things that you can do to make FaceRig footprint smaller on your setup:
1. use FaceRig at a lower resolution, you can go as low as 960x540. I assume you are using FaceRig as webcam view, so the view is already small.
2. use a lower setting in the game you are streaming, after all, you are basically streaming two games (resource wise)
3. use window capture instead of FaceRig Virtual Webcam and disable Broadcast. There is an option to hide the interface.
4. limit FaceRig's refresh rate to 24-30 fps. Go to General Options > Performance Tab.
5. Camera resolution needs to be low (General Options > Resolution).

review:
Already worth it. Going to use the pseudo-camera it generates to pop into my work meetings and troll the heck out of anyone and everyone. I am particularly happy with the turkey, the white potato with a face sitting in a bowl, and the creepy sandwich. Installing it in Ubuntu to see how it works there. Confirmed working in OBS studio, though I'm too lazy to stream otherwise I'd have bought the pro pack. Only hitch is that there are no obvious quickguide/instructions - had to figure out to turn on broadcast in order for it to output to the pseudo camera.

Also meant to add that in order to improve tracking, I moved the camera closer to me so that the top of my head and bottom of my chin with my mouth open was about 4 wingers-width away from the edge. I had to get a little creative to get it that close since it normally balances on top of my monitor (and doubt I could do that with built-in camera on a laptop), but given how it appears to function that only made sense. 720p res on my logitech camera seems to be the sweet spot for this thing.

Another update - as of Proton 4.2 (the thing that trys to let Linux Steam try and run Windows things) it doesn't run in Ubuntu 18. Not surprising b/c it wasn't meant to... but just thought I'd mention it. You can get something to come up when bypassing the launcher... but the inherent problem with virtualization and Wine in particular (which is what it looks like) is that the hardware isn't transparent... so I doubt it would ever work using Proton. 

Works fine in a Windows 10 VM using Virtualbox and letting the VM capture my USB camera. Granted, you need at least an SSD to host the VM, a 4th gen i5 (3rd gen i5 laptop studdered) and enough free memory (assigned 4gb) to avoid significant lag though. Don't bother if you plan on using a spinning disk especially if you are recording locally. You can use Window capture in OBS Studio to capture the Virtual Box Screen and then use the Crop/Pad filter to get rid of the top/bottom/left/right elements left in the screen that you don't want. 

All this just to troll the guys at work. Isn't life grand?

Facerig is fun to use, but not for the price.

Don't get me wrong, Facerig is definitely fun to use. It is fun to mess around with the different skins and features, but that is all that this software offers. Once you mess around with each character, you will get bored quickly and quit being amused by them as easily. As for the fundamental selling point, it works just about as well as you would expect. It is not perfect, but the face recognition isn't bad at all.

On the down (and more technical) side, the interface is absolute Hell to navigate and makes doing almost anything just about impossible without watching tutorials. Not only is the interface very irritating, but the software doesn't allow you to save your user settings. Why doesn't it?! You can save all of your work, but not your settings and configurations? Every time you boot Facerig up, you must reconfigure everything to run it. It is very irritating having to do that every time!

If Facerig was just a whole lot cheaper, I would recommend buying it. For the price, you could get something that would last you a whole lot longer and something that would have the replayability of a fun game unlike Facerig. If a sale comes around, I would pick it up. Until then, keep this software on your wishlist!

developer_response:
Hello, are you running, in parallel, another game? Adding FaceRig to your streaming configuration (stream software + game) will add some CPU/GPU load. Note that face tracking and high quality rendering come with the CPU and GPU resource cost, so if you are running a game at high quality graphics option, you may have frame drops.

There are some things that you can do to make FaceRig footprint smaller on your setup:
1. use FaceRig at a lower resolution, you can go as low as 960x540. I assume you are using FaceRig as webcam view, so the view is already small.
2. use a lower setting in the game you are streaming, after all, you are basically streaming two games (resource wise)
3. use window capture instead of FaceRig Virtual Webcam and disable Broadcast. There is an option to hide the interface.
4. limit FaceRig's refresh rate to 24-30 fps. Go to General Options > Performance Tab.
5. Camera resolution needs to be low (General Options > Resolution).

developer_response:
Hello, I use FaceRig daily and my setup is not the most professional. You just have to make sure that *enough* light reaches your face (so as to not be obscured cause then the tracker will not be able to track you). A lamp on your desk (if it's dark outside) would suffice; it doesn't have to shine directly into your face. I'd argue here and say that this software is not a gimmick; its intrinsic value is not to attract attention, without having any substance. It is frequently (if not daily) used by streamers and YouTubers and other creative content creators. People from the marketing world, education and even the health sector have used and are using FaceRig, so this part is subjective. If you do not see its value and usefulness, that does not mean it doesn't have one. 

Regarding the problems that arose with your software and hardware, we would like to hear more about them. You can create a thread on our Community forums and we'll find a solution.

developer_response: FaceRig is advertised as a *software* which enables anyone with a web-cam to embody an avatar, rather than a game. It is meant to be an open creation platform so everybody can make their own characters, backgrounds or props and import them into FaceRig. I'm sorry to hear it was not perfect for your needs, though.

review: how do i make a custom character

(videos at bottom)
I'd recommend having a good gaming rig to get the best performance. I get the best results at 1280x720 on my i5-3570k, 4gb gtx970 and 32gb of ram. Using a Microsoft Lifecam Cinema camera, max res is 1280x720 also.

Note: Before I get started one big con with this software is it requires some manual setup that might not be clear for many users. FaceRig downloads and installs along with it's DLC, but, and there's always a but hey? You need to install a couple of apps buried in [b]teamapps\common\FaceRig\Bin\prerequisites[/b] for FaceRig to fully work with other programs like Skype and Discord.
The software should really automatically install and uninstall what it needs.
Also check your DLC page, you may have to manually install the Pro license DLC manually as that also does not automatically install either.

Software summary:
It's a fun program, lots of customisation and content for the base price. Models are high quality and animations overall are good.
But it can be a lot of trial and error to get it working right. Setting the right animation, animated or targetted? The right lighting, camera qualiity, overall PC specs and graphics resolution and quality.
Nail it and the lip synch can work well, fail and your avatar will look like a bad dubb. 

But be prepared to read the manuals if you want to get the most out of it. The program has a lot of options to mess around with.

Basic is good for messing around on Skype/Discord and pranking your friends and for $15 bucks it's worth it I reckon.
I'd be cautious about getting a pro license. I have it and from what I can see there is no difference between it and the basic version.
Pro just alllows you to use the program commercially like on a monetized youtube channel.
If you aren't monetizing your content don't bother getting pro.

Also FaceRig only exports to webm format. No more popular formats like .mp4 etc.
To get other video formats you must buy FaceRig studio for a couple hundred bucks.

The export video quality of the webm is poor imho. But that can be solved by using an external capture program like OBS or nVIdia's Shadowplay/Share to record the FaceRig window at a higher quality and a format of your choosing for free.

FaceRig Studio also allows for much more detailed puppeteering too I beleive and is more aimed at commercial application than every day use.

DLC wise it's not too overly priced for new avatar packs and there are many, and they often come on sale. 

So yeah, for me it's a yes for basic. It is a good price for what it is.
Having to install drivers manually is a pain and I'd love to see some optimizations regarding performance and improvments in mouth tracking/synching.

As for pro and studio I'd think hard before parting cash for them.

Here's a video of FaceRig in action.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=idgUej2rIgc

Update: New video of a live stream using Facerig with everything workingmostly right.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EFVc5Wqcpnw

developer_response: Hello, more often than not FaceRig starts losing the tracking due to the poor lighting present in the background (the light shining from the back, hence the face being obscured; or shining too brightly on the user's face, thus the tracking being unable to correctly interpret the facial features). Make sure the environment is well lit and that you keep a neutral face when you calibrate the tracker. If you've still problems with it, you can start a thread on our Steam Community forums with a more detailed description of the issue and we'll investigate it.

developer_response:
Hello, there is a reason for the 'paywalls' that you've pointed out. The Live2D technology is an external software and, in order to be used, it has to be purchased. Furthermore, you need to take into account the fact that FaceRig (with or without the Pro upgrade) and FaceRig Studio are built with various 3rd party technologies, such as an externally licensed expensive high-end face tracking system, and those parties wouldn't allow having the tech be offered freely. 

You can stream freely with the base version of FaceRig, but only if your revenue is equal or less than $500 per month. Only when the revenue passes this amount users have to purchase the PRO DLC Upgrade.

Regarding your reported issue with the Windows 10 blue screen, you can start a thread on our Community forums detailing it so that we can start from there; we always respond to threads created there.

review: this game sucks

For someone that wear glasses, IT IS NOT RECOMMENDED. Have you noticed the trailer video? noone is wearing glasses. If you do, facerig software cant pickup your eyes movement. Or to put it better, it always thinks your asian and gives you half closed eyes. Thumbs down. It should be mentioned on the description with BIG letters.
developer_response:
Hello, for one, I am wearing glasses and have no trouble using FaceRig. Indeed, there are a few tweaks to be done, such as disabling winking - one of the major issues that glasses can cause is the program misreading your eyes (often because of glare) and assuming that you are blinking when you aren't. To fix this, go to "Customize Avatar", click on the "Special Actions" tab, and then scroll all the way to the bottom. There will be a box ticked with "Enable Blink" beside it. Untick this box.

The second option would be to "Widen your eyes" - the "lazy eye" appearance, is due to the fact that FaceRig misreads your face thanks to your glasses obscuring your eyes a little. This can result in the program thinking your eyes aren't open properly. To fix this, go to "Advanced Face Tracking Calibration", click on the "Expression Units" tab, then adjust the parameters for "Left Eye Closed" and "Right Eye Closed" to compensate for the tracking errors your glasses are causing.

To summarize, FaceRig has problems misreading your eyes due to the glare from the lenses that might be due to a light source that hits your glasses directly, and also due to thick frames that obscure your eyebrows. 

Here is a pinned topic on the problem with glasses that you've described: https://steamcommunity.com/app/274920/discussions/2/613935404221245524/

Hello, for the best experience a good web camera and microphone are recommended. Seeing as FaceRig is a tracking based software, it requires a good web-cam that has little to no noise and a good resolution. If the user does not calibrate the avatar and the environment around is not well lit, then the tracking will suffer.

Regarding the problems with the interface, it would help if you described them in a detailed manner. Is your instance of FaceRig lagging? Make sure you meet the minimum requirements which are shown on the Store page (they are based on Desktop systems, and not netbooks or laptops).

developer_response:
Hello Boxie, 

I use glasses and have no problems with FaceRig. Here's a pinned thread with best practices for users with glasses: https://steamcommunity.com/app/274920/discussions/2/613935404221245524/ 

The main issues when it comes to tracking users with glasses is lighting, most importantly lens glare and the size/thickness of the frames which can interact with eyebrow tracking). 

Many of our users use it frequently (if not daily) in their Twitch streams, so it comes down to each and every user's use-case.

developer_response:
Hello, regarding your bad experience with glasses, know that there are a few things one needs to keep in mind: if the glasses have thick frames, then they will most probably be confused with the user's eyebrows; then there's also the fact that the glare from the lenses will interfere with the tracker, thus misreading your eyes. I also wear glasses and making sure that you are in a well lit environment will lessen the glare from the monitor upon your glasses' lenses. For example, I don't use auto-blinking and the tracker has no problem in reading my eyes' behavior. When it comes to fine tuning the tracker and expressions, we have a comprehensive tutorial, which will come in handy: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=315322209.

Regarding the Geforce Experience, it does not have an option for changing the camera source; FaceRig‚Äôs virtual device works with any software that uses and lets the user select webcams as video sources, it doesn‚Äôt require any additional integration, so that is why you have to rely on 3rd party programs such as OBS.

Hi, 

If you have issues with a program, I strongly suggest that you contact the support team. Our team constantly responds to user inquiries on the Steam forum.

1. use FaceRig at a lower resolution, you can go as low as 960x540. I assume you are using FaceRig as webcam view, so the view is already small.
2. use a lower setting in the game you are streaming, after all, you are basically streaming two games (resource wise)
3. use window capture instead of FaceRig Virtual Webcam and disable Broadcast. There is an option to hide the interface.
4. limit FaceRig's refresh rate to 24-30 fps. Go to General Options > Performance Tab.
5. Camera resolution needs to be low (General Options > Resolution).

[h1]How FaceRig Ruined My Life[/h1]

I loved this program, it allowed me to unleash my inner waifu. The face tracking limitations from the software itself and the half-baked models did not stop me from using it. 
However, they forced me to exaggerate any facial expression that I wanted my characters to display - this was the start of the end for my life.

Hours of making the most sickening and unnatural faces in real life, only to achieve normal results within the software, my face was slowly getting deformed - any expression I made outside of the virtual world has become creepy and unsettling. A smile that I pictured as normal, now became twisted into something that would make the Joker cry. A sad face that should illustrate my depression and make the people witnessing it feel my pain, now became something to laugh at, as I became a blob fish that's been stepped on a few times for good measure.

My mother could not take it anymore and broke down crying, seeing her once normal son who turned into this abomination, eventually deciding to disown me and burn my computer that caused it all.

I ended up living on the street and have been shunned even from the homeless community, which I am now supposed to be a part of. I am now known as "Sh!t Face Supreme" by everyone in the community. It is truly unbearable and I want to end it all - I plan on visiting the people who made this program and give them a serious punishment, simply taking a look at my face will etch terror and fear into their souls, I am certain of it.

Regardless, this program deserves a solid sh!tfacesupreme/10, as it allowed me to find a few hours of joy before taking my life away from me.

I recommend this if you want to fulfill your dreams of being an anime girl.

developer_response:
Hi,
Adding FaceRig to your streaming configuration (stream software + game) will add some CPU/GPU load. Note that face tracking and high quality rendering come with the CPU and GPU resource cost, so if you are running a game at high quality graphics option, you may have frame drops.

There are some things that you can do to make FaceRig footprint smaller on your setup:
1. use FaceRig at a lower resolution, you can go as low as 960x540. I assume you are using FaceRig as webcam view, so the view is already small.
2. use a lower setting in the game you are streaming, after all, you are basically streaming two games (resource wise)
3. use window capture instead of FaceRig Virtual Webcam and disable Broadcast. There is an option to hide the interface.
4. limit FaceRig's refresh rate to 24-30 fps. Go to General Options > Performance Tab.
5. Camera resolution needs to be low (General Options > Resolution).

    We have streamed on twitch actually, and we had no issue on a mid-range computer (i5-4690 and nVidia GTX 750). We streamed Rocket League and Don't Starve with FaceRig running as a facecam. Unfortunately, the vids aren't available anymore.

review: This tool looks fun, but useless for streamers, its just makin fps so so low! I bought itfor streaming, but no point to use it as performance of the game is really low with facerig.
developer_response: Hello, it is worth mentioning that face tracking and quality rendering come with the CPU and GPU resource cost so it is only naturally to have a few frame rate drops if you are running a game at high quality graphics option. The refresh rate of the application is set to 60 fps by default. Turning it down to 30, or even 20-25, could greatly help as it clears some CPU usage. Go to the Advanced UI, General Options, Performance tab, and change Main App Frame Cap. Make sure you are running FaceRig on DX11, it will clear some of the CPU usage, on some avatars the CPU usage is half of the DX9 version. Change this option from the Launcher, Render API. You can also use FaceRig at a lower resolution (you can go as low as 960x540), or use window capture instead of FaceRig Virtual Webcam and disable Broadcast (here is an option to hide the interface).

Well folks..... This is a great bit of software.
However it COULD be made much better with just one simple addition.

Let the user grab the face tracking dots to position them.

Simple!

The big problem with this software is calibration of the face and motion. Dont get me wrong it does a really good job automatically, but it could be much better if you could use the software to move some of the dots about.

This becomes clear when you see the lip/expression syncs on some of the models.  Now ok, not every model is good for expression and lip syncs... but some of them like the deamon should be up to the task. I believe that it could be improved significantly if the user could "tweak" the auto tracking.

Also while the webcam is usable, it is far better to pre-record video and use that as a input-feed.... you get way better results.

One other area that could be better is the menu and sub-menu links.  They are not intuitive enough so you kind of have to dig about and mess too much to set things up.

I know this software is still growing and the devs are working on it, so I cannot wait to see how it develops. 

When all is said and done I do recommend this software, and provided they change some of the menu set-ups etc this program could become a great bit of kit. :-)

Keep up the good work guys!

Alright, since people seem really knit-picky for clarifications, let me clarify why I had difficulties with this program.

I had the original intention of buying this to create an animated avatar that I would use in place of a webcam in my Let's Plays and reviews. I was excited to try it out again, but I ran into a problem: there's no detailed tutorial for how to properly go about making an animated character. I'm a visual learner myself, so I instinctively searched on YouTube, only to find glossings of the subject. I went to several websites and found nothing noteworthy.

After a few hours of digging, I went back to the software and sat thinking: is this really worth the trouble if the community doesn't create a dedicated guide? I only say this because the guides aren't that much more helpful. After pondering the thought for about an hour, I decided to refund Facerig.

Before I refunded Facerig, I wanted to run some tests on my equipment with this program. I used several microphones and webcams, but found the lip-sync and motion capture to be unresponsive across the board, even through a few configuration changes. Some webcams and microphones worked better than others, but not to the degree that Facerig promises.

I come back to this review while skimming through my reviews because I felt like I wasn't clear in my experience before. Well, now I'm being clear when I say that Facerig isn't exactly bad, but it's more of a tedious process to do the simpliest of things. A friendlier user interface and possibly some developer tutorials would be nice additions to the software.

this is great but it dosent let me download more dlcs i got the presidental one and it wont let me get anyother one it says its in my libray but its not instaling dlcs please help me.
developer_response:
Hello, this issue is common with Steam and you can resolve it pretty quick. 

- Make sure FaceRig is shut down
- Right-click FaceRig in the software list in steam
- Select "View downloadable Content"
- Make sure the checkbox is checked
- Close the window and wait for Steam to finish downloading (It might look to be stuck at 0 bytes for a while, this is a problem with steam, just be patient)
- Launch FaceRig and they should now be there.

If the download doesn't start, try playing any other game for like five minutes and then return to the DLC tab in the games's Properties. If the DLC is already checked, un-check it, close, wait 5 minutes, then re-check it.

review:
I recomment this but with limitations and weird design choices that severly reduce the fun in it.

My biggest gripe is with exporting: Every Video is recorded in a weird playback Format and needs to be exported before it can be watched with anything but the Program itself. This is not uncommon but weirdly unuseful and infuriating in this program.

This format is useless as the Audio and Video are out of sync, so even if you have to crop or somehow change things you will need to do so after making it into a video. 

Now why the Program doesn't have an option to record straight to video is mindboggling - or at least have the exportprocess started automatically after recording, if the in-between-step is necessary. If you try to make a few small clips with it, and do multiple takes on them, just the exporting makes you go mad - especially because you can always only select one video for exporting. Why cant I select all 10 Takes and the program exports them one after the other?!

With that said, the Program works fine and if you have a decent setup with a good PC enough light and a good camera it does run pretty smoothly. I am using a a 7700k and a Logitech C922 and it never loses my face, even if I move my arms. or take a sip from my cup. The taken Processor Power never goes above 20%, even when livestreaming it to skype.
developer_response:
Hello, 

The format that you're referring to is .rpl and its purpose is replaying a performance with a different setup than it was recorded with and visualizing the performance
in real-time with any mix of avatars, props, backgrounds, light tuning, post process effects, etc. What you want to do is record a video and export it without
going through the replaying of the performance. This can be done by switching to "Basic UI" and selecting the "Record a performance and then export it as video" option. After recording your video, you can export it as .webm and then convert it to other formats with the help of third party converters or online. You can find an
audio-delay slider in the Sound settings and that setting is there because in many cases the video and audio paths have different delays (for instance, even Windows
sometimes buffers the audio for pre-processing so it can cause a delay). So, the delay is caused by the fact that FaceRig has to buffer a bit of the sound to do
an analysis. By delaying a bit of the sound with the help of the slider, then the combined output (lip motions and audio) will be in perfect sync. If you need more
information on what the setting does and how to use it, feel free to contact us at info[at]facerig[dot]com.

review: MOOOOOOOOOOD
It's fun to play around with and can definitely mastered with time. My only gripe is the exporting process is handful with the WEBM codec and trying to get it to be an MP4 file.
developer_response:
Hello,

The reason you can only export videos on FaceRig Classic as WEBM is because adding support for the .mp4 format would mean also adding the cost of said license to the entire price of the Classic version. We do have the option of exporting as .mp4 in the Studio version since it is a version designed for professionals and companies.

developer_response:
Hi,
FaceRig's main purpose is to provide creative people a tool to entertain their family and friends. It can be used to make videos, make comic books, gifs, create 2D or 3D avatars, broadcast on chats like Skype or Hangouts, stream, etc. There are numerous uses for it, some of them we didn't even anticipate, but were pleasantly surprised when our users presented them to us. 
For example, a user used FaceRig to decorate his house on Halloween and scare passers by with live characters who spoke to them.
There are as many uses of FaceRig as creativity permits (:

review: racist software, half asain and doesnt register my eyes as open.
developer_response:
Hi,
Considering that the software company we licensed the tracker from is from Taiwan, it's a bit of a stretch to assume that the tracker isn't suitable for Asian people.

Keep in mind that a neutral expression calibration is mandatory for a good experience. 
If you don't do it correctly, and the program misbehaves, it does not mean the program is racist, it just means that you are not using it correctly :)
A video on this can be found here: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BB_bxGF2JWM&t=4s

Also good lighting always helps, and you might need to calibrate the tracking tools, a tutorial for that can be found here:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=315322209

review: MAJOR resource hog
developer_response:
Hi,

There are some things that you can do to make FaceRig footprint smaller on your setup:
1. use FaceRig at a lower resolution, you can go as low as 960x540. I assume you are using FaceRig as webcam view, so the view is already small.
2. use a lower setting in the game you are streaming, after all, you are basically streaming two games (resource wise)
3. use window capture instead of FaceRig Virtual Webcam and disable Broadcast. There is an option to hide the interface.
4. limit FaceRig's refresh rate to 24-30 fps. Go to General Options, Performance Tab.
5. Camera resolution needs to be low.

developer_response:
Hello Oddballs. Thank you for the nice review and for the feedback.
There are two ways to autosave your prop load-out. One of them involves quick save slots for characters (you have 10 of those) the other involves toggling on the Autosave function for the entire program.

The Autosave function :
Go to the advanced UI ( UI+ button) -> General options ( cogwheel icon on the right) Preferences-> General and  toggle Autosave On. From now on almost all your settings ( program/avatar/tracking settings/color customisations/props etc) will get auto saved on exit, or when you change an avatar. So if you customise Fluffo, then go to The Lava baron, and then when you go back to Fluffo, your last used settings for Fluffo will auto load. This method can be a double edged sword sometimes though, because if you mess up some other settings, they will also get auto saved, so you will have to remember to manually reset faulty settings to defaults when strange things happen :). So only use autosave if you are well knowledgeable of what settings affect what aspects of the program , so you are not surprised when disaster strikes :).  As a safer  alternative to auto-saving everything  we have implemented, avatar quick-save slots.

The Quick save Slots
After you have configured a certain avatar as you like it (distance from the camera, background, props, colors etc)  simply press  Ctrl+Shif +1, and all of that will be saved on avatar quick save slot 1.  To load the contents of avatar quick save slot 1 , press  Ctrl+1 ( without shift) .  You can have 10 total spots for quick saves, keys 1 to 9 and also 0 :). This way you can have up to 10 characters pre-set, hot-swappable, and can even do like dialogues between them :)

If you have further questions about this system  you can always ping us on the forum or at info[at]facerig[dot]com . :)

Regards,
The FaceRig Team :)

HI i can not start it its saying error c0000135 help?
developer_response:
Hi,

That Windows error usually appears when a required DLL file ( either by the OS or by FaceRig) could not be located. This can happen because of missing installation files or logical drive errors ( among other things, but those two are the most probable) .
 
Please make sure that
 
- FaceRig was installed when the Steam installer was running with administrator privileges.
- There are no missing FaceRig files( right click on it in the steam Install folder and choose " Verify Integrity of the Local Application Data Cache")
- All the redistributables from the [SteamLibraryFolder]\FaceRig\_CommonRedist\ were successfully installed as well.
- you run a disk check on your drive to make sure there are no logical disk errors.
- your antivirus is not blocking the Steam client or any of the installers from writing their files in the FaceRig folder.
 
If you still get the error even after the above please read the pinned thread here http://steamcommunity.com/app/274920/discussions/2/34096318703798146/
and mail us the data mentioned there , with a link to this thread ( if you haven't already) .

developer_response:
Hi, we have actually reproduced this issue on a fresh install of Windows 10, and we are working on finding a fix.

To detail a bit what the issue is, the redistributables install correctly, but somehow the OS provides a 64 bit of d3dx9_43.dll or in your case d3dx9Compiler_43.dll, while FaceRig is a 32 bit application, hence the issue.
If you search the web on this issue, there are tons of posts for all games and apps out there with tons of solutions that don't actually work.

Please also make sure that your antivirus software isn't deleting FaceRig files and preventing it from running properly. We do not recommend disabling the AV, but rather that you add an exception for the FaceRig folder.
It is also possible that the redistributables did not install correctly so I suggest re-installing them. Just go to <steamInstallDir>\SteamApps\common\FaceRig\_CommonRedist\ to find them.

FaceRig's main purpose is to provide creative people a tool to entertain their family and friends. It can be used to make videos, make comic books, gifs, create 2D or 3D avatars, broadcast on chats like Skype or Hangouts, stream, etc. There are numerous uses for it, some of them we didn't even anticipate, but were pleasantly surprised when our users presented them to us.
For example, a user used FaceRig to decorate his house on Halloween and scare passers by with live characters who spoke to them.
There are as many uses of FaceRig as long as the users' creativity permits (:

review:
I first purchased this product in October of 2016. It was fairly fun to use, I even used it in some livestreams. I refunded it not long after, however, not becausse I didn't enjoy the product--but rather because it kept reading my glasses as being my eyes and so my expressions would be distorted. It would make it look like Fluffo either had a severe case of lazy eye or some type of damage which prevented his eyes from staying open. While it certainly gave me many laughs, it bothered me that there was no way to effectively compensate for this without losing a degree of functionality. I need my glasses on to be able to see at all, being extremely nearsighted. It was my hope that they would come to accomodate for users who have to wear glasses all of the time, or otherwise have their trackability by the face-detection software be impaired.

Instead, when I reacquired the software on June 9th, I was disappointed to find that the face-detection still interpreted my glasses as being my eyes--even more so than when I first tried FaceRig. I had gotten a new pair of glasses since the last time and thought that maybe after a few months the software would have been improved or other methods of compensating for problems that wearing glasses cause with face-detection would have emerged.

FaceRig is a unique program, to be sure, and definitely one that you should try out for yourself. But be warned, if you have to wear glasses all of the time, the face-detectin owill in all likelihood see part or all of your glasses as being your eyes, and you'll be left with awkward, twitchy and otherwise unpleasant facial expressions. 

All that aside, FaceRig is worth the cost. It's my hope that the program can be made more accessible to people who wear prescription glasses 24/7. A thoroughly amusing and at the same time frustrating experience, but one that I still enjoyed immensely.

review: Facerig is a fun program to use occasionally.

So far I have not had good experience with this.  I personally have a full beard, and it does not see my mouth "out of box."  If I run through its calibration it might work for a short time, but generally will start to show signs of issues within minutes.  Some models are more forgiving.  This is not terrible, as it was meant for my wife.  The only issue is that for some odd reason this software seems to think her left eye droops.  Only, on her actual face it doesn't.  Not even a little.  Calibration does not help with this.  Repositioning the camera does not help, nor adjusting zoom.  It might be ok for a bit, but if she moves her head a little then returns to a neutral position, it's like the character has a lazy eye.  It does the same thing for her sister.  No clue why.  Talk about a self-esteem killer that costs money.  She won‚Äôt touch this thing now.  Sticking your tongue out does nothing with the characters, and there is supposed to be a key you can press on the keyboard to do this, but this does not work either.  No, I can't recommend this.

Some additional info:  I am using a Logitech c920 webcam for capture.  I have turned off "right light" which is necessary for 30 fps capture at 720.  Everything is set to auto, but I have tried playing with manual setting to see if more or less contrast/bright/saturation and trying to ensure as little grain would help the software.  I have better that typical lighting as I have a studio light stand in with umbrella diffuser pointed at my face and 3 good over head lights.  All 85 watt CFL 5500k temp if the devs know or care what that is.   I also tried using the software‚Äôs ability to take a recorded source and apply the character to this.  I have some much better cameras I tested with.  I used a Sony Z1U which is a full professional broadcast camera from about 10 years ago and a Panasonic v770 which is my goto camera and those videos have shown the same issues both for my wife and for myself, so it seems to be an issue with the capture algorithm and not the camera.  I would be more than willing to go over anything else with the devs on request.
developer_response:
Hi,

We created a few guides/tutorials for users who have issues with the calibration.
If the calibration and lighting is done right, it can work on bearded people as well. Here's a video with two bearded colleagues of ours:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t84XuR_A6YE

Make sure your face is as fully in the webcam-preview as possible, without the top/bottom of your face being cut off. Make sure that your face is well and evenly lit against a background that isn't a window or an other light-source:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=315322209

Regarding the tongue movement, that is a feature that can't be achieved with regular cameras, since they can't see depth. That is why an infrared camera is for.
You can use the key driven tongue by enableing Special Actions from the Avatar -> Behaviours tab and then pressing S and clicking on Mouse Right.

MINIMUM:
OS: Windows¬Æ 7 or later
Processor: Intel¬Æ Core‚Ñ¢ i3-3220 or equivalent
Memory: 2 GB RAM
Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce GT220 or equivalent
DirectX: Version 9.0
Storage: 3 GB available space

I cannot stream without frame drops or screen tearing. I have google fiber(1000mb/s up&down) and a reasonably powerful desktop.
developer_response:
Hi,

Adding FaceRig to your streaming configuration (stream software + game) will add some CPU/GPU load. Note that face tracking and high quality rendering come with the CPU and GPU resource cost, so if you are running a game at high quality graphics option, you may have frame drops.

There are some things that you can do to make FaceRig footprint smaller on your setup:
1. use FaceRig at a lower resolution, you can go as low as 960x540. I assume you are using FaceRig as webcam view, so the view is already small.
2. use a lower setting in the game you are streaming, after all, you are basically streaming two games (resource wise)
3. use window capture instead of FaceRig Virtual Webcam and disable Broadcast. There is an option to hide the interface.
4. limit FaceRig's refresh rate to 24-30 fps. Go to General Options, Performance Tab.

We have streamed on twitch actually, and we had no issue on a mid-range computer (i5-4690 and nVidia GTX 750). We streamed Rocket League and Don't Starve with FaceRig running as a facecam. Unfortunately, the vods aren't available anymore.

developer_response:
Hi,

Since other streamers manage to have daily streams with FaceRig and another game, it should be a clear indicator that the program does what we say it does. 
As with other software, you should have a system that meets the recommended requirements to have the best experience.

Adding FaceRig to your streaming configuration (stream software + game) will add some CPU/GPU load. Note that face tracking and high quality rendering come with the CPU and GPU resource cost, so if you are running a game at high quality graphics option, you may have frame drops.

Also, we do not take care of the billing, it is a known Steam rule that if you play more than two hours, then you can not be refunded, we can not help with that.
