review: Finally, I can be a transgendered elven princess like I've always wanted.

I found this easy to setup, very intuitive to use, and cute as a daggone button!  Make sure you use the advanced features to see all the options, and color variations for each character.  Used it to create an homage to my favorite YouTubers.

https://youtu.be/sUFdypC_eB8

This piece of software is not only badly designed, its fundamentally flawed from the get go.  This is just an outright bad idea to go with.

First off, the concept of face tracking itself.  This method of motion tracking using a visual camera is abysmal.  It takes far more resources than any other tracking method.  Its only benefit is that you can use a generic camera that any person will be likely to have, but more on that later.  It does not scale well at distances; in fact, it is very picky where you put your face at all.  Minute lighting differences or wearing glasses has a drastic affect on tracking quality.  Tracking with a single camera is also very limiting to this software‚Äôs uses.  Being ‚Äúphuny‚Äù on a YouTube video or a Skype call is about all you can do with this.  Its so picky with tracking that you basically have to sit in a single spot, barely dispacing yourself from initial tracking or else risk losing all the tracked animations.  You can forget about looking in any direction that isn‚Äôt in the camera‚Äôs general direction.

Secondly, the hardware. If you use a $20-40 webcam you got at Walmart, you are gonna have a very bad time.  Of course you would want professional recording equipment if you wanted optimal results for something like this, but FaceRig performs so poorly its basically mandatory.  The developers even go so far as to say you NEED a 60FPS camera; something that is pretty important, but is NOT a standard for PC web cams.  Majority of web cams on the market cap at 30 FPS because they are not intended for this kind of use(expected use is video chats, which focus on limiting visual data for better streams).  This isn‚Äôt a big deal for YouTubers, who would have the necessary equipment AND the know how to configure a proper setting for it.  Your general prank Skype callers will quit of frustration.  Speaking of the YouTubers though!

Yall are gonna have to pay up for an extra, professional license if your channel is popular.  Honestly?  Spend your money else where.  Plenty of better, cheaper gimmicks that end up looking far more entertaining than this crap.

You know why all the screen shots have this excited, ‚Äú:D‚Äù face to them?  Its because that is the easiest face for this software to pick up accurately.  In actual use, you will find awkward glitches in the tracking constantly.  Again, unless you are a YouTuber with good equipment, you‚Äôll make a fool of yourself in a way you didn‚Äôt intend for; buying this garbage for $15.

Mentioning pricing reminds me: do you want to use all the anime grills people have made in the workshop?  Do you want to use workshop content at all?  Because fuck you, that‚Äôs another $4 just to have the right to access them.  The entire workshop is filled to the brim with 2D Live content.  I could only find 3 regular FaceRig mods in my search.  I subscribed to 2 of them, 1 crashed the application.  In the off chance that you want to make your own 2D Live character, you are in for an even bigger world of hurt.  The application needed to make the characters is developed by an entirely different third party, whose based in Japan.  Majority of the quality tutorials are in Japanese. Its also quite a bit more expensive than this app itself; as opposed to regular 3D models which can be made in open source modeling applications such as Blender.

One thing that completely baffles my mind: a pre-recorded video of someone‚Äôs tracking performance can yield different results when fed into another PC opposed to the live performance.  Its so mind bogglingly shitty, I really can‚Äôt explain how you can mess up an app that bad.  Perhaps I should take it up with the forums, but I really don‚Äôt care at this point.  The tracking is inaccurate anyway.  You will be fighting with it constantly, trying to find the optimal sitting arrangement just so you don‚Äôt have to worry about it derping out every 3 seconds.

Lastly, to extend on the point of this awful design, visual motion tracking is both inefficient and, at this point, obsolete.  Emitter based tracking has taken over this department.  Its a bit more niche, considering that you need very specific, extra hardware along with the software, but it performs so much better with less overhead on the CPU.  It scales better, it detects better, and it can be run with a single standard design.  Even if you use visual tracking, using something similar to the PlayStation Moves colored ball design is far superior than trying to keep track of every possible configuration of skin tone, head/mouth/eye size, hair/glasses, etc.  It would be silly, but I would EASILY prefer wearing some skin tight mask and software specific camera than using this.  This app is worthless to me, and should be to just about anyone else.  By the time you spent money on professional recording equipment and the DLC packs you want, you could have easily purchased something a lot more entertaining and useful.

PS:  Why do you have achievements?  Why does any kind of software have achievements?  I don‚Äôt use software to feel like I have done something cool, I use them to help MAKE something cool.  That isn‚Äôt gonna happen with this.
developer_response:
Hi,

I'll reply to you inline for each of your complaints.

[Cabby] This piece of software is not only badly designed, its fundamentally flawed from the get go. This is just an outright bad idea to go with.

[Aty] FaceRig's main purpose is to provide creative people a tool to entertain their family and friends. It can be used to make videos, make comic books, gifs, create 2D or 3D avatars, broadcast on chats like Skype or Hangouts, stream, etc. There are numerous uses for it, some of them we didn't even anticipate, but were pleasantly surprised when our users presented them to us.
For example, a user used FaceRig to decorate his house on Halloween and scare passers by with live characters who spoke to them.
There are as many uses of FaceRig as long as the users' creativity permits (:

[Cabby] First off, the concept of face tracking itself. This method of motion tracking using a visual camera is abysmal. It takes far more resources than any other tracking method. Its only benefit is that you can use a generic camera that any person will be likely to have, but more on that later. It does not scale well at distances; in fact, it is very picky where you put your face at all. Minute lighting differences or wearing glasses has a drastic affect on tracking quality. Tracking with a single camera is also very limiting to this software‚Äôs uses. Being ‚Äúphuny‚Äù on a YouTube video or a Skype call is about all you can do with this. Its so picky with tracking that you basically have to sit in a single spot, barely dispacing yourself from initial tracking or else risk losing all the tracked animations. You can forget about looking in any direction that isn‚Äôt in the camera‚Äôs general direction.

[Aty] When we came up with the idea to create FaceRig, we decided to first market it for the home user, and then for businesses.
Regular users will have low end webcams and yes, they come with some limitations. But that is exactly why we recommend that our users have the minimal requirements devices and have light in the room. We have several tutorials and guides online that helped users having issues with the tracking.


[Cabby] Secondly, the hardware. If you use a $20-40 webcam you got at Walmart, you are gonna have a very bad time. Of course you would want professional recording equipment if you wanted optimal results for something like this, but FaceRig performs so poorly its basically mandatory. The developers even go so far as to say you NEED a 60FPS camera; something that is pretty important, but is NOT a standard for PC web cams. Majority of web cams on the market cap at 30 FPS because they are not intended for this kind of use(expected use is video chats, which focus on limiting visual data for better streams). This isn‚Äôt a big deal for YouTubers, who would have the necessary equipment AND the know how to configure a proper setting for it. Your general prank Skype callers will quit of frustration. Speaking of the YouTubers though!

[Aty] I think you misunderstood our messages. FaceRig works with any webcam. But if you want better results, we did recomend special high end equipment.  That does not mean that we recommend that everyone should use that special equipment. It depends on the results each user desires.


[Cabby]Yall are gonna have to pay up for an extra, professional license if your channel is popular. Honestly? Spend your money else where. Plenty of better, cheaper gimmicks that end up looking far more entertaining than this crap.

[Aty]We do still need be sustainable as a business long term, in order to keep improving FaceRig, adding features and content so that's why the program can't be free; and we also need to convince our tech partners that using their tech in a low cost product is a good idea,  so we had to include limitations for commercial use. So that's the main reason any FaceRig Classic and FaceRig Pro have commercial use limitations, that's why we have a fairly complex EULA and that's and why Facerig Pro costs more (because it starts to have some commercial use).  However, most users who pass the $500 monthly revenue seem to understand why they would have to pay more for a professional tool that helps their channels grow.


[Cabby]Mentioning pricing reminds me: do you want to use all the anime grills people have made in the workshop? Do you want to use workshop content at all? Because ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you, that‚Äôs another $4 just to have the right to access them. The entire workshop is filled to the brim with 2D Live content. I could only find 3 regular FaceRig mods in my search. I subscribed to 2 of them, 1 crashed the application. In the off chance that you want to make your own 2D Live character, you are in for an even bigger world of hurt. The application needed to make the characters is developed by an entirely different third party, whose based in Japan. Majority of the quality tutorials are in Japanese. Its also quite a bit more expensive than this app itself; as opposed to regular 3D models which can be made in open source modeling applications such as Blender.

[Aty] Yes, the Live2D Module is licensed from Live2D in Japan. But they offer a free version for any content creators who do not want to use their tool commercially. As for the tutorials, we've provided English as much as we could:
http://steamcommunity.com/app/274920/discussions/8/485624149164823989/


[Cabby]One thing that completely baffles my mind: a pre-recorded video of someone‚Äôs tracking performance can yield different results when fed into another PC opposed to the live performance. Its so mind bogglingly ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, I really can‚Äôt explain how you can mess up an app that bad. Perhaps I should take it up with the forums, but I really don‚Äôt care at this point. The tracking is inaccurate anyway. You will be fighting with it constantly, trying to find the optimal sitting arrangement just so you don‚Äôt have to worry about it derping out every 3 seconds.

[Aty]Of course it does, it depends entirely on the machine you are running the program on. A machine with the recommended requirements will perform better than one with the minimal requirements.


[Cabby]Lastly, to extend on the point of this awful design, visual motion tracking is both inefficient and, at this point, obsolete. Emitter based tracking has taken over this department. Its a bit more niche, considering that you need very specific, extra hardware along with the software, but it performs so much better with less overhead on the CPU. It scales better, it detects better, and it can be run with a single standard design. Even if you use visual tracking, using something similar to the PlayStation Moves colored ball design is far superior than trying to keep track of every possible configuration of skin tone, head/mouth/eye size, hair/glasses, etc.

[Aty] I do not understand why you would complain that FaceRig Pro and the $4 Live2D Module cost too much, and then suggest that we should change the tracking technology with one that would make the whole program's cost skyrocket.
However, we are working on implementing other sensor into FaceRig for those who can afford it. For example the Leap Motion DLC is free on our side, but you need to buy the special camera to use it. Just like the Intel RealSense DLC.
Also for FaceRig Studio we are going to release a PercePtion Neuron module, which will have a much better accuracy.


[Cabby]PS: Why do you have achievements? Why does any kind of software have achievements? I don‚Äôt use software to feel like I have done something cool, I use them to help MAKE something cool. That isn‚Äôt gonna happen with this.

[Aty] For the people who love to collect them (:

developer_response:
Hello,

 Take a look at this tutorial for calibration
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BB_bxGF2JWM
Also, it works well if your glasses are not reflective. Reflective glasses block line of sight to your eyes. This is most noticeable in a dark room when your computer monitor is the brightest light source. If you don't have non-reflective glasses, try putting the brightest light source behind or beside you instead of in front.
Also, glasses with thinner rims are preferred since they block less of your eyebrows.
You can also use the advanced tracking settings (and the settings in the avatar behaviour tab) to compensate for oddities.

There is a lot to like here. The idea of using avatars online is really good, but the software is poorly executed. Areas such as needing to manually recreate adjustments made to the tracking EVERY TIME you go to use the program and constantly needing to recalibrate the audio quickly get irritating. Created recordings have audio glitches in them, making the program TOTALLY unusuable as anything but a toy.
developer_response:
Since the beginning of the project, we have made great efforts for a small start-up to provide a good software for a decent price. We are still indies and we always improve and polish FaceRig so users can get a better experience.
Calibration needs to be done everytime you access the program.
In order to achieve proper calibration, you will need to maintain a neutral position.The lightning in the room is also important, if you are in a very dark environment ,you will need to put the light source in a matter of way to fall on your face so that the tracker will be able to see you. We have made this tutorial to help 
users get the best out of FaceRig. Take a look here
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BB_bxGF2JWM&t=1s
As for the recording glitches, do write on our forum more info so we can investigate what's happening.

review: amazing
I like it and its usefull ,but its too much for my cpu and its a AMD fx 6 core.
developer_response:
Hello,

There are a few tricks to get a better performance:
Make sure FaceRig runs in Dx11 mode not DX9 mode 

Lowering the FaceRig render resolution does not help the CPU that much, just a bit. Capping the FaceRig main thread framerate helps a lot more, and so does setting FaceRig as a lower priority process. 
The refresh rate of the application is set to 60 fps by default. Turning it down to 30, or even 20-25, could greatly help as it clears some CPU usage.

review:
Very minimal review here.

If you don't have glasses and want to use it - go ahead, thumbs up.

developer_response:
Hello Tf2 Dove,

We are sorry your initial experience was not ideal. 
The problem in most cases are not necessarily the glasses, but either:

1. the light setup that causes your glasses to give off strong reflections 
2. less than ideal framing (face too far away from the camera, so there's not enough pixels to work with for the tracker). 
3. Maybe lack of a proper  neutral expression calibration ?

Because, in certain light setups, of the lens light reflections block the camera's view of your eyes, the program cannot track what it cannot see in the webcam feed. 

Disabling tracked blink in the Avatar behaviour, and altering your light set-up a bit will vastly improve your experience.  Also there is this pinned thread in the forum with extra information: http://steamcommunity.com/app/274920/discussions/2/613935404221245524/

Regards,
The FaceRig Team.

Great product however the only and massive downside hence why I cannot recommend this is the CPU usage. Using a 3770k at 4.7ghz when I run Facerig in games my CPU usage maxes out at 100%. This causes games to stutter so badly that they become unplayable. I have tried the recommended suggestions by decreasing the default 60fps to 30fps (I went as low as 20fps) and it didn't resolve anything. 

So for anyone getting this to stream games whilst the tracking and avatar selection is good when it comes to practical use Facerig fails.
developer_response:
Hello Majnu,

We are sorry to hear about your experience with FaceRig being a negative one.

However the amount of facerig videos that you can find from Twitch streamers on Google, Youtube and Twitter and Twitch   (For instance  https://youtu.be/Iye30ej4bjA?t=1m7s  )  do tend to show that this is not a common  issue, many streamers do manage to configure the FaceRig settings so that they do get good performance while playing games.

For instance:
In regard to CPU performance the largest positive impact is given by running FaceRig in dx11 mode, instead of  DX9 (launcher setting). 
One other thing that you can try to do is set FaceRig as a lower priority process ( in preferences/performance, within FaceRig). 
For GPU bottlenecks, setting a lower render resolution should be enough.

Hard-limiting the FPS or the tracker thread can also help but should be among the last things on the list:).

Regards,
The FaceRig Team

review: This is a really fun way to entertain friends, my only wish is that my poor potato of a computer were able to handle more than just this program at one time.
noice i can be a doggo
I love it. Now I can have a burger face.
Altough it's laggy for me, it's still worth-buying for shy people want to do game commentories.

If Facerig worked the way it was advertised... if...then I could see a lot of potential in it.

However, with the measly laptop I came to Steam with it wasn't going to happen. Was Facerig one of the reasons I decided to upgrade? Actually, it did factor in.

So, shiny new computer tower installed, widescreen monitor, webcam, microphone... everything was ready.

Facerig did not disappoint.

I was looking for something to create stories on for school, something the kids could take home or be sent to parents over social media, something a little more interesting than an audio recording and it hit that spot straight away.

So, I used it on and off until it came to organising a Halloween event for the school. With a little planning and a Skype setup, we arranged it so the students had a locked-room challenge, hosted by a Halloween monster (thanks to one of the DLC packs).

Sure, Skype support has been problematic lately, but that's Skype, not the software. Give yourself a half decent webcam, a decent lightsource and remember to keep your expressions animated and this will deliver the goods without fail. It's a great toy and a great resource and when I brought it in for Halloween, my colleagues were perhaps even more impressed than the students.

As long as you know what this does and what you're getting yourself in for, then I thoroughly recommend this software.

The interface is easy to use and you'll be flying around it quickly enough, the range and resolution of the avatars is superb and the addition of 2D avatars is a neat touch. Good stuff.
developer_response:
Thank you for the awesome feedback! 
And if you've got a link to the Halloween video, please share. We'd love to post it on our social media channels.

developer_response:
Hello,

If you use FaceRig for streaming, your PC needs to be above the minimum requirements so that lagging will not occur.

You can try this for better performance:

First, the refresh rate of the application is set to 60 fps by default. Turning it down to 30, or even 20-25, could greatly help as it clears some CPU usage. Go to the Advanced UI (last option from left to right on the top bar), General Options dialog, Performance tab, and change Main App Frame Cap. 
Make sure you are running FaceRig on DX11, it will clear some of the CPU usage, on some avatars the CPU usage is half of the DX9 version. Change this option from the Launcher, Render API.
Change some graphics options to clear some GPU *and* CPU resources utilization. Change the render resolution to 640x360 (try out different values to see what suits your needs) and the shadow map quality (go to Low) from General Options dialog, Graphics tab. You can also tweak the Fur Quality, Skin Shading Quality and Use Animated Normals, to balance performance and visual level to your needs

review:
Saying this first, don't buy this if your only purpose for this purchase is messing with it, there's not much fun outside of having some cartoon character doing funky faces.  No, this product is more for content creators, who either want to display their reactions without showing their real face, being displayed as an actual living avatar, or just as some roundabout joke thing.

Even with [i]Ubisoft's Your Shape's[/i] crappy webcam that I always use for this, FaceRig reproduces my facial expressions well enough, and there are a lot of in-depth option settings to fine-tuning the avatar's reactions, such as eyebrows, lower lip, etc.

There already exists many avatars to choose from in the main build, which you can customize to an extent, and there's also Steam Workshop where you can also use user-made models (most of which is for the [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/neon_henchman/recommended/420680/]Live2D DLC[/url] though).

I mean sure, go for it if you think that'd be funny, it sure was when I included it in some of my videos.
developer_response:
Hi Neon Henchman,

Thank you for an awesome feedback.

review:
I use this during my Streams and my chat really enjoys it.
If you want to see it in practice come check it out at twitch.tv/L1feRemaining every night :D

This is a nice piece of software and I hope the audio portion of the program gets some kind of tweaks to stabilize it so people do not have to keep re-installing the pre-requisites. Having said that, It is also the most aggravating piece of software I have ever run across in the audio department. I bought it to use in conjunction with Morphvox Pro for a special purpose for children's lessons. Yes it is true that my Computer is not a high end desktop system but it holds it's own with this stuff but it is constantly losing it's ability to have the playback loop work. With and without the Morphvox software running. I have gone thru all the settings many, many times and re-installed the pre-requisites over and over. Sometimes the second pre-requisite does not re-install without first going into the control panel and deleting it there as per computer instructions because ocaisionally install_webmd refusing to finish installing unless you uninstall first and then it requires a computer reboot before it installs correctly. I have done the virtual mic, screaminbee when Morphvox is running, windows mapper, my mic and every other combo to get playback loop up and working again while recording to no avail. It has become so frustrating to me I am just dumbfounded. Sometimes even the mouse will hover and highlight every single option except the exact one you are trying to highlight (i.e. devices) I am not a complete idiot either as I do actually hold a degree in computer science and have messed with computers since the TRS-80 model 1 which I bought in 1981. The audio stability of this software is just something to be desired. So I go ahead and record without playback loop audible and when I load in the .wav file or the movie, it of course has recorded without any effects that I had assigned and that is without Morphvox open and just using the in-house effects. I have a Logitech h390 headset with mic and the sound comes thru fine and is heard easily but just not the playback loop.
I would send in a copy of the logs but to tell the truth I promise I tried that setting already !!  This is just more of a rant after owning this product for 48 hours and logging at least a 1/3 of that messing with it's functionality and performance. It really is a good product and killer animations but the audio portion stinks. At least from where I am sitting right now !!

review:
I don't like to give bad reviews on a product. Facerig is a god send for a person that wants to keep their real life self hidden from the internet using a mask of a character. The problem is that making your own 3D character to work with this software is a pain and have a high risk of failure. It is a shame. I had high hopes for this software. 

I commissioned somebody to design a 3D model for facerig and he soon run into trouble. He tried to get support to get it working, but support ended up turning their back on him. I tried to see that facerig devs can expand their rigging services, but instead I was told to throw the person that commissioned back into the lion's den. He soon came back telling me that it didn't work out as once again they became quiet. He told me that we may not be the target audience for this software and I agreed with him. They did turn their back on us twice. 

I wanted it do a youtube video on my channel to complain about facerig, but I couldn't figure out how to do it without breaking my character and going OOC. Right now the only thing I can do is warn people that making avatar for this software is a high risk thing and the community is slowly disappearing. I wish you luck if you continue.
developer_response:
Since the beginning of the project, we have made great efforts for a small start-up to give our users the possibility of bringing their own creations into FaceRig. 
We've posted the step by step documentation for the public and even offered help   to anyone who asked. As you can see on the workshop, users have successfully uploaded their own 3D models.
We have answered you each time and we have offered to complete your avatar with the only request that you need post it on the workshop. We can't do more than that now, as we are working 24/7 on the mobile release.  Being a small team we have to prioritize our projects and if our art team didn't give you enough details on how to finish your model (although I seriously doubt it), then please just write to them again and ask them to give you some feedback about your 3D model.

review:
[h1]Why I got this[/h1]
It allows me to talk like my Freekin blue 4 eyed lizard alien avatar! (imported my own character)
And it looks so fluently and dynamic that my friends gets creeped out at times!

[h1]How I discovered it[/h1]
One of my danish friends decided to use it in a skype call, when i watched him talk like a wolf that way I asked about it at once! Bought it as fast i found out about the character import possabilities.

[h1]Do I reccomend this?[/h1]
First of look at my time using this software.
Then look at my main reason.
If you love pretending to be things or roleplayting this is a go! Especially if you like cosplaying, I call this the ultimate digital cosplay software! You can be anything if you make it! Like my avatar used in my steam pic. (which i made)
I say you cant find anything better for free. And I cant see anything better for money either. Software renders itself as an virtual webcam usable in any software that accepts webcams.

[h1]How did i get my own character into this?[/h1]
Well i had this avatar i made a little while before knowing this softare, basically an alien i made in spore and exported to later on modify allot in blender (improving the look and adding more realistic suitable clothes). Then i read through the manual several times and experimented with the example characters aviable. Then i made my own character working the the whole head with tongue and 4 eyes working and everything. I knew a certain amount of how blender worked which is why i could pull this.

Later on i did an upgraded version of my blue personal character with 2 working arms beside the head. And the whole body visible with a wagging tail behind me.

I also got an character released at the workshop (guess what) another character made in spore but modified a little later on. Worth a look!
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=667724881
lolololololololololol ITS SO AWSOME! lololololololololololo!

Very cool idea and in their limited amount of avatars this software does it's job well. However, if you're thinking "Wow this is really neat, I want to do a custom one!" forget it unless you are a full on 3d artist with about a month to spend on rigging and prep.

Technically yes, you can create custom models but, trust me when I tell you...it's daunting. The 2d models are easier because there's some better tools to use but if you're wanting to add a new model or do something custom then you might want to pass on this software as it's just not there yet.

Another thing is their documentation. You'd think that a company would just create a spot on their website with all their documentation or any help files, but no...their documentation is spread out all over the place, forums, steam, inside threads created by others. So not only is it EXTREMELY difficult to add any sort of customization, the documents that you will need to do that is literally spread out all over the place.

In the end, it's a very promising peice of software but until they get a definitive set of documentation, some better tools, and refining the avatar creation process this unfortunatly limits this software to just a gimmick.
developer_response:
Hi there,

We have created FaceRig with the intent to be an open platform.
The documentation necessary for creating a 3D model is in one place right here http://steamcommunity.com/app/274920/discussions/6/485622866436709756/.
Indeed it does require some skills to create a 3D model and as for tools, you can use Blender , Maya or any other 3D software as long as you follow the documentation.
Our 3D artists do provide support and feedback for the rigging part and they can be reached via email here artsupport[at]holotech[dot]eu.

developer_response:
Hi,

Does your laptop meet the minimum requirements.
Here they are: MINIMUM: 
OS: Windows¬Æ 7 or later 
Processor: Intel¬Æ Core‚Ñ¢ i3-3220 or equivalent 
Memory: 2 GB RAM 
Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce GT220 or equivalent 
DirectX: Version 9.0 
Storage: 3 GB available space 
Sound Card: DirectX 9.0c compatible sound card 
Additional Notes: For image based tracking you need a webcam. For sound base tracking you need a microphone. The requirements are based on desktop systems, not mobile (netbooks, ultrabooks, laptops, tablet pc). The mobile versions of processors and graphics adapters are not equivalent to the desktop ones. If you have a mobile PC please make sure the charger is plugged, you are running on the best graphic adapter and in high performance mode. We do not recommend low end integrated graphics adapters.

If it does and FaceRig still does not work then you will need to provide us with the Vp.log and dxdiag files like here http://steamcommunity.com/app/274920/discussions/2/34096318703798146/ so we can investigate.

review: Finally, you can use your webcam and protect your anonymity without having to wear a facial-expression-obscuring mask!

FaceRig is an amazing piece of software that is a lot of fun to use.   It is a little confusing between the different versions of the software that are available though.  The hardware requirements are different (IRFacerig is strictly for the Intel RealSense camera and FaceRig is for regular webcams.)   I purchased FaceRig and then saw their demo on youtube of using the Intel RealSense cameras with IRFaceRig.  I was impressed with the demo, so I purchased an Intel RealSense SR300 camera and then downloaded the IRFacerig program.  Unfortunately, the IRFacerig program is missing a lot of features that FaceRig has.   One of the developers of FaceRig responded that this is by design since the IRFacerig version is free and FaceRig is a paid version.  The recent version of FaceRig does accept the Intel RealSense SR300 camera as well,  but I have not figured out successfully or found documentation on how to do facial and hands tracking the at same with FaceRig and a RealSense SR300 camera with FaceRig. (Or which avatars support hands tracking).  I am also experiencing audio issues after the software is running for a while that requires me to do a device reset on the Audio Devices inside FaceRIg's device control panel.

One these limitations and bugs are fixed,  this will change the world of low cost real time motion tracking.

review:
[h1] I can be an Anime Character	[/h1] 
[b] 10/10	[/b]

For years, I've dreamt many, many times about something like this, as to whether someone can impersonate an Anime character on the news or represent an established subculture with powerful fiction. 

No longer must I look to a parallel dimension for the possibility of its existence. It's already here! Anyone can impersonate one of the many 3D sprites in Facerig, with each of them rendered in high quality for recreation and professionalism. 

With the Live2D expansion, anyone can become the anime character of their dreams üëåüèº Since the DLC only released half a month prior to this review, there'll be much work to do on the Steam workshop. In addition to the plethora of suitable backgrounds at your disposal, there's also the option for green screens, enabling you to use any background you wish from your files subsequent to saving your recorded performance. 

Facerig makes Skype more fun, and gives flavor to otherwise bland TV Production videos; it's a must-buy for anyone with a webcam and a valiant sense of humor :)

review: Best way to not show your face on skype.
fun but not the kinda difficult when you have low light, also feel lip syncing could be improved
developer_response:
Hi,

For the audio based lipsync we do recommend a quality headset with a good noise canceling microphone optimal lipsync, as any background noise may interfere with its accuracy.
Also make sure that you don't have lag inducing sound effects ( called enhancements) activated by default from Windows on your microphone, such as acoustic noise cancellation. Those add up to 0.2 second delay on the sound before it even reaches FaceRig so if you have those activated naturally the lip motion is a bit behind.

It's even good for video making and has a green screen too.

review:
After looking at the review for this and having now used it, I'm having a hard time believing the positive reviews. 

The problem I have is the lipsincing, no matter how I mess around with the settings it still pretty useless. You record your speech, then play it back the mouth movements don't match the sounds. I don't think there are enough points around the mouth to mimic the complex movements.

I won't be recommending it, in fact I will be requesting a refund.
developer_response:
Hello,

The lipsync module is an audio based tracker that detects the phonemes from spoken tongue and translates them as atomic animations applied to the avatar.
We do recommend a quality headset with a good noise canceling microphone  optimal lipsync, as any background noise may interfere with its accuracy.
Also make sure that you don't have lag inducing sound effects ( called enhancements) activated by default from Windows on your microphone, such as acoustic noise cancellation. Those add up to 0.2 second delay on the sound before it even reaches FaceRig so if you have those activated naturally the lip motion is a bit behind.

review:
I bought it. I've spent over an hour with it, during the day, at night, with lamps on both sides of my monitor to light my face evenly, with glasses (avoiding any reflection at all), with contacts, after trimming my beard to the 4mm minimum I'm willing to do, all while using a fairly decent HD Logitech webcam. The avatar will slowly shake it's head with me, do some stiff nodding and slow blinking, and every now and then it'll catch some movements I make with my face, like raise an eyebrow or move my mouth left and right. It might start moving it's mouth like it's talking when I make a sound. That's about it.

Here's my primary experience so far. The left eye is half closed most of the time, winking with my left eye does nothing, winking with my right eye closes both eyes, it randomly opens the mouth and won't shut it until I reset the calibration, it smiles when I frown, it smirks with one corner of the mouth when I smile, the mouth doesn't even hint at trying to move with mine when I talk, but humming a tone into the mic makes the avatar start moving it's mouth like it's holding a speech (so if I clearly articulate a long "KAAAABOOOOOMMMMM" it'll do something random more along the lines of "weabolalaoooahlagaoubomadaou" - probably leaving the mouth open at the end), the (random) mouth movent has a massive delay so even with some imagination it doesn't look like it's the one talking... The fact that Facerig "cheats" to emulate talking by making random mouth movements when you pic up sound on the mic shows that the devs even know the mouth-tracking doesn't work.

You'd think I'd have the most difficult face in the world to track, but I've been blessed with a fairly symetrical face, I'm white with dark hair (so you'd think eyebrows would be the easiest thing in the world to find), have no blemishes to get confused with, and sport a light, well-trimmed beard. My face certainly doesn't go in the "difficult to track" category and I've tried lighting setups that are starting to border on professional.

Facerig is pretty much on par with the gimmicky stuff that used to ship with webcams 6 or more years ago, when it comes to how well it works. I own a ton of games and take chances on early-access things often, but this is one of the few times I'm pretty disappointed. The only thing it has going for it is that the 3D models are nice and it's fantastic that it'll be opened up to people to develop their own models (hopefully through Steamworks). The software itself is made with some strange, old-looking, custom interface, where each type of setting opens up in a different, separate window, and quite often they don't even open the first time you click on the corresponding icon. I simply can't think of a single redeming feature beyond the nice-looking models and the associated customization/lighting. Absolutely everything around the avatar models themselves kind of, well... sucks.

So, it's fairly obvious why I don't think this is ready for sale at all - early access or not. This is barely free, open-beta, prototype material considering the core-functionality is barely dragging itself along. The interface might get a complete overhaul, but I kind of doubt it. It's likely to keep looking like one of those nVidia 3D tech demos. And that's where I get to my point. This is a 3D tech demo. Not an application. I truly, truly, wish it was - otherwise I wouldn't have bought it.

---

PS. I can tell a lot of work has gone into this, and I don't mean to bash the team. I know how hard it is to work in a startup and I wish them tons of success. Hell, you trippled your IndieGogo goal and you're front-paged on Steam, so I'd say you've hit some major milestones and major congrats are in order for that. People want what you're promising, and I'm obviously one of them. However, this is a pretty lousy result of more than a year of work and hundreds of thousands of dollars. I'd honestly toss out ALL the programming, keep the models and start over with a proper interface that doesn't look like you took inspiration from ten-year-old versions of GIMP and Blender. I'm almost certain that you let the 3D designer(s) think up the interface as well. Take on some guys who did a master's thesis or PhD on face-tracking to build that part. It's not easy, but it's most certainly not the rocket-science you make it out to be. I know you won't start trashing all the code, though, since that's one of the hardest things to do in start-up-land, but what you've spent so much time and money building barely works at all, and that's a very bad sign. It means development is truly slow (which is fatal for a start-up, for reasons ranging from dying motivation to loss of market interest and severe second-mover risks) and it points toward thinking that you've got some magic under the hood that can't be done better. Believe me, it can with the knowledge you have now. You know that it's not even close to how well you imagined it to work. Focus on that.

March 2016 Update:
Two things: Snapchat and MSQRD. I hadn't given any thought to Facerig again until these two MOBILE APPS suddenly introduced face-tracking as a free gimmick and did it a hundred times better, and I thought to myself "hey, didn't I blow $20 on a crappy piece of software that didn't come close to this?" Seriously, if a little team like MSQRD can come up with far superior face tracking with probably a fraction of the time and funding on freaking mobile phones, that just goes to show what a failure this is. If I could thumbs-down Facerig twice, I would. There are far better, free alternatives. I'm sure the Facerig team had a collective kool-aid-drinking fit when they heard that Facebook bought MSQRD. Did I mention the terrible face-tracking before? Second-mover risks? I think I did.

Facerig, even with the most proper lighting and ideal settings, did not work for me. No amount of troubleshooting fixed it, and I decided that a slight asymmetric feature of my face (my left eyelid droops EVER SO SLIGHTLY-- almost unnoticably unless you're looking at my eyes side-by-side and I just told you about it.) was causing the on-screen avatar to have a stroke and a seizure at the same time. Even holding my eye wide open and sitting perfectly still, portions of the avatar's cheeks and jaw jiggled and twitched aimlessly and when moving my mouth to lip sync, it only moved about every other word.

If you're really interested, and you're hopeful for a working FaceRig, I would either ensure that it works for you, ensure that you're using ideal settings (both computer settings, and real life contextual settings such as plain, bright lighting and sitting a specific angle to your webcam) and even then don't be surprised at the unfortunate hiccups, twitches and other immersion-destroying issues.

Not a bad product; not a bad project; not a bad idea.. just... doesn't work. Often. Let-alone working as demonstrated in the videos.
developer_response:
Hi,

We constantly offer support and assistance on our Steam forum so any time you encounter issues or you have questions we are here to help. As for twitchy avatars, a proper calibration needs to be done in order for the avatar to behave like in this tutorial https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BB_bxGF2JWM&index=2&list=PLwxwPv-15rVtP1S1DnkP7S6lZoFjAmY2k

For a twitchy avatar you can adjust the smoothing slider which can be located by switching to Advanced UI then select Advanced Tracking Configuration and by Selecting the Body and Head Pose you can adjust the Smoothing Slider.
If the avatar does not have the eyes opened then the calibration has not been done correctly.It can either be because you did not registered a neutral position from the beginning or by not fine tuning the eyes.
This can be done by switching to Advanced UI then choose the 4th top option from the right side menu. There if you go to Expression Units - Eyes you can adjust the sliders based on sensitivity. Here is also a tutorial to guide you through this process http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=527751224&insideModal=0
You also have the option to turn off or on the audio based lipsync. The audio based lipsync can be found both in Simple and Advanced UI, it's the one that looks like a mouth. It is also recommended to use quality headsets with good noise cancelling microphone for optimal lipsync, as any background noise will interfere with its accuracy. When the lipsync is on it means that the audio based tracker detects the spoken language and then translates them as animation applied to the avatar.
Any time you encounter issues, don't hesitate to contact us and we will assist you.

developer_response:
Hi,

The launcher is not meant to advertise DLCs, regular avatars are there that come with the base program.
As for the crash do you have Avasta antivirus? If so, you should check if it is blocking FaceRig. If this is the case, then this is how to Exclude FaceRig in Avast. Open Avast user interface. Go to Settings. (Gear icon) In 'General' tab open 'Exclusions'.In 'File paths' paste the path to FaceRig. Press Add. Press OK
Close Avast user interface. You can then launch FaceRig.
For any issues encountered we are available on our Steam forum, providing support.

become the anime

From the time I was a child, I always wanted to be a hamburger. My teacher would ask, "Little Cheshire," (distinguishing me from Big Cheshire), "what do you want to be when you grow up?" I would happily answer, "A hamburger! A hamburger on a toasted bun with sesame seeds!" My teacher would chortle as she answered, "Why, Little Cheshire! You can't be a hamburger! You have to pick something realistic like a prince or an astronaut!" Then she would turn, still laughing, to the next child in line who would announce their desire to be a dinosaur cowboy upon reaching adulthood.

Despite what my grade school teacher said, I never lost sight of that dream. I would often coat myself in ketchup and mustard, then sprinkle seeds in my hair and stare into the mirror for minutes at a time, willing myself to become a hamburger. However, this bit of role-playing never fulfilled my desire to be a hamburger.

Now, now my dream will finally be realized. My first order of business will be to record a video of me as a hamburger and send it to my grade school teacher. I'll say, "MMmmmMMMMMMM!!!!!" (For, of course, hamburgers cannot speak English.) She will know instantly who I am, and will type her response as tears of regret roll down her cheeks and onto her keyboard. "Little Cheshire," she will type, "I was wrong. I was so wrong." My hamburger self will smile as I read her response, knowing that all the while, I understood that I was right to dream of being a hamburger, most noble of all handheld foods. I will be able to throw away my economy-size bottles of ketchup and mustard, my large jar of sesame seeds, knowing that I have achieved my dream finally.

I don't really know what to say other than, "meh".

This software isn't really that great, but it's a step forward in terms of getting this kind of feature into the consumer market, so I'm okay with supporting it. I purchased it specifically because of the Live2D module, but that's also been a bit disappointing.

The face tracking is fine, but the rigging and parameterization aren't really up to snuff, so the subtler gestures of the human face are really under-expressed, and the more overt ones are sometimes overexpressed. There's also little accounting for the differences in expressiveness between the various human facial structures and ranges of human physical expression. Some people show teeth when they smile, some don't. Some people's lip edges actually point downward when they frown, some don't. Some people open their mouths wide when they speak, some people make subtler lip motions. I can see the tracker keeping up with all of this, but the model does not seem to account for it correctly. Tuning is long and tedious and only helps a little bit. Most furstrating, though, is the [i][b]significant[/b][/i] latency in the model's expression.

I don't think Holotech has been lazy here. I think the tech is just still in its infancy. Live2D was particularly disappointing because the range of expressiveness for the models tends to be so very low to begin with.

Still, I consider this to be prototypical tech; breaking ground in a new consumer segment. I'm hoping that FaceRig gets some competition and that all of the involved tech (especially Live2D) makes large strides forward.

Yes!!! Finally, this software is awesome and I really wanted to keep it at first but I thought I would disregard it but now with the new dlc. I can finally be satisfied :D And for those looking for a real review. Just scroll up or down. There's tons of them.

I bought a brand new high-quality webcam for the sole purpose of using it to make myself Doge.
I can't say I'm disappointed.

One of only downsides I've really face is the fact I wear glasses, and that can kind of mess up the eye tracker. While this can be pretty much fixed by disabling the eye tracking/enabling autoblink or ajusting light to fix glare, it makes me sad that I can't squint or look surprised with those features disabled/enabled. So, if you have glasses, this still can work, but you may want to look into using contacts with this instead (or be like me and give up on your glasses and use this blind).

The only other downside I've found is that I prefer to use a headset to talk (if I used my webcam, there would be a bit too much background noise) and the headset can mess up the ability for the software/webcam to see some facial expressions. However, this could be fixed by getting a standalone mic that would just sit on a desk, but still block out background noise.

Overall, this was totally worth buying a brand new webcam that I will never use for anything else.

Even since this software was first revealed to the public as a crowdfunding project, I've seen it to be this massive pocket of potential just waiting to happen. I tried it myself and found it rather disappointing (for reasons detailed below), but I still have not changed my mind about the fact that it has a lot of potential. It is a shame because I actually wanted to purchase the Pro license so I could broadcast with FaceRig.

- Most facial features (eyebrows, chin, forehead, etc.) on most avatars tend to jitter like crazy, rapidly and haphazardly fluttering even with my face up-close and perfectly still. I have a good camera, and I did try to play around with the "Smoothing" options that were designed to get rid of this facial capture anomaly, but to no avail. This may sound like a minor issue, but it really hinders performance when I encounter it. I looked in the website's forums for this issue and found only one other user who had it, and his query is yet to be answered.

- Some characters severely lack certain expressions. For example, the "wisdom" guy seems to be unable turn (not tilt) his head sideways, except through manual controls.

- Sort of related to the above issue: It is very difficult to have a character shake its head "yes" or "no" without anomalies. For example, the ghost in the Halloween DLC is almost incapable of doing a coherent head shake. He is also unable to nod "yes" without his eyebrows erroneously registering a series of scowls and raised brows. This was especially discouraging because I liked this character most.


- I noticed some characters completely lacked customization options, such as the aforementioned ghost. 

It seems to be all these issues may eventually be solved while this software continues to be developed and improved. However, in the state in which it is now, I find it almost unusable at worst, experimental at best. My refund request is pending.

If you really like what this software offers and don't care about the technical issues listed above, then I see no reason why you should hold back. However, I personally recommend waiting until it is at least in a better state, especially if you plan on going professional with it.

Wasn't what I thought it would be. The face tracking wound up being very simplistic, similar to what you see in Google Hangouts or Snapchat's new facetracking filters. It just followed the eyes, eyebrows, and whether the mouth is open or closed (but not more subtle movements like making an "O" with your mouth). I appreciate the effort and intent here, but unfortunately it just doesn't deliver. For example, if I make a sad, pouty face, the avatar will often smile. If my bottom lip curls up over my top one, into a pout, the avatar's bottom lip should curl up over its top one. There also weren't nearly as many avatars as I was expecting--and many of them were limited to just one gender. So, for example, there was only a female alien, no male alien. This reduced the number of possible avatars for me to select from.
developer_response:
Hello Schmell,

Most of the issues you mentioned can be addressed by properly configuring the program.
Take a look here at what a proper  configuration can produce : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iLohwYLxVxs

What's especially important:

- framing your face in the camera correctly (not to small/far away, and not cut off by the image edges) 
- proper lighting (for instance we've seen many screenshots taken in dark rooms with the only light being what comes off the monitor, which is needless to say bad for image-based expression tracking) 
- setting up a neutral pose and expression correctly 

We do agree that using for the first time expression mo-cap technology does have  bit of a learning curve associated with it, but we trust is worth learning to use the program correctly (if used improperly we agree the results will not be stellar, like in the examples you've given). 


Regards,
The FaceRig Team

review:
Even without the Anime DLC this is worth the price of admission. You'll have a field day creeping out people with your burger face. Even better if you coordinate a dance routine and make it sing songs.

It's basically Gmod but with your face. Endless possibilities.

FaceRig is a fun yet simplistic tool capable of motion/facial capture and application to animated models. Facial tracking is pretty inconsistent with 3D Models, and the success of it depends largely on the the hardware and the person's facial features (some people can get good capture...others it won't even work with). The Live2D however is much more consistent in performance, likely due to its simplified tracking and parameters....such that it is more forgivng with regards to facial changes. Overall a full recommend....you can have yourself animated easily with this hardware, and although its applications are essentially novel...its still worth the modest price.

This app has a lot of potential but its shortcomings make me wish I didn't spend the money. The face doesn't match my actual expressions very well and only a limited range of expressions are possible. I can smile, I can kind of squint my eyes (but sometimes the eyes act weird). I can shake my head no, but if I nod yes, it confuses it into thinking I'm closing my eyes because it can't even figure out that face getting shorter = angle changing. Somewhat understandably, it doesn't track my hands, but that's a huge handicap when I talk with my hands (I'm part Italian, it seems to be in my blood). Really, the advantage of seeing my face or an avatar is that you can see my expressions. If I can't make half the expressions I want to or even make gestures with my hands, then it's no better than a phone call with no visual representation.

I used this with MorphVox to modify my voice and the effect was kinda nice. It would be cool if this app had better voice changing abilities to actually match the characters, although fixing the flaws in the facial expression tracking is a much higher priority.

Also, the fact that this is Windows-only is a huge bummer. I would prefer Linux and Mac as well as the main thing I'd like to use this with is Skype, which is already cross-platform and I'm not on Windows most of the time. Having this on iOS and Android would also be a plus if I'm still somehow able to use this with Skype (might not be possible though).

So in short, my dream of leaving my mortal carcass behind to be an anime girl must be deferred.... for now

developer_response:
Hello Scorpion_CR1,

Sorry to hear about the negative experience with FaceRig. From your review we get the feeling that perhaps you did not yet understand what the neutral expression calibration is for, or how to perform it correctly. Please make a thread on the Steam Troubleshooting forum with details about these problems (if you can, also send us a captured facecam feed) and we will help you out with information on what is wrong with your mo-cap set-up.   As you may imagine that the program wold not have had an 85% positive rating if poor tracking was the norm, but we do agree that it is a bit more complex way to interact with the computer, than just via mouse and keyboard or controller, so there is a learning curve especially for those who have not worked with mo-cap before.   

Regarding the black feed: There's actually a specific pinned thread in the Troubleshooting section to help those who are seeing a black feed in  Skype (usually the answer is deceptively simple : folks simply forget to toggle broadcast on in FaceRig or  are unaware of the fact that in Windows only one program can use a webcam device at the same time http://steamcommunity.com/app/274920/discussions/2/523890681411352799/ ).

Regards,
The FaceRig Team

developer_response:
Hello  Over 9000!!!!!

We're sorry to hear about your negative experience with FaceRig, and while of course you are fully entitled to your opinion, you are presenting very inaccurate information in this review, as seen in the following examples.

1. The Virtual Camera Driver does exist and it does work (it just needs to be properly installed and properly configured).  
Simply look up recent videos on YouTube with FaceRig on Omegle or Chatroulette, there are LOTS of them, made by various people,  and they all use the FaceRig Virtual Webcam driver.
https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=facerig+omegle
You can do the same for Skype and such.

2. The voice would match the character's lip motion if the user picks free-form retargeting avatars, like here:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iLohwYLxVxs   
and/or if the user has enabled and configured the audio based lip tracking correctly, like here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iUQSHZ4lmxY

There is a bit of a learning curve with FaceRig for users who have never used mo-cap software before, but that does not mean that good results cannot be obtained once you learn the basics :).   

In closing:  we do not claim that the program  is perfect, ( far from it, there are many legitimate bits of critique that we pick from the steam reviews and user forum and integrate in our development plans), but what was described in your review is ... something else entirely. 

Regards,
The FaceRig Team

[h1]Jokes aside, this is my first impressions on FaceRig C:[/h1]

I'm loving how this software works, very impressive! Although the eye contact may be distorted if you happen to wear eyeglasses, but i'm pretty sure the issue has been addressed  already long ago (basically the lighting reflected on the eyeglasses causes the eyes to go nuts on screen). This really affects mostly to 3d characters rather than the 2d characters from the dlc "Live 2D Module".

The calibration between webcam and screen is fantastic! It's fun to make interesting expressions, and I take an interesting advantage of this for sketching. [b]Yes, sketching![/b] It's very good practice, to me that is. It's like drawing in art class with a live model.

Anywho, I've haven't put much hours onto this. This is literally a first impression of FaceRig, but I got some cool ideas in terms of practice and development for illustrations.

Great job Devs, cheers!
It is pure bliss for having fun with a good webcam :D

Works great....in good lighting conditions! In conditions with fairly poor lighting, such as a bedroom, the camera cannot detect face movement so well, which makes the avatar "twitch". Unless you have the right lighting gear, I'd only advise using this during the day.

Level of customisation in the softwear itself is basic; there is also no guide built into the softwear on how to import your own models or textures, making the level of modding and self-use rather limiting unless you know where to look.

Overall it works well and does what it says on the tin, but needs a little bit more work doing to the guide to cover people who want to import their own work, for that extra personal touch.

developer_response:
Hello Rabbit Box,

A recent Windows update seems to have had adversely affected two Microsoft Windows redistributables related  Visual Studio that were also needed by FaceRig. This is not a FaceRig specific issue, and is easily corrected by re-installing the mentioned redistributables.  We suspect that is most likely the issue that was affecting you and we would have guided you on how to do that  had you made a post with the needed log files on the Bugs and Troubleshooting forum.

The links you have posted in your review are rather old (one is from more than a year ago when the program had just entered in Early Access, other is from about 5 months ago immediately after the program launch).  Many aspects  have changed since then, and those threads are not representative of the current program state by a long shot. 

Please realize Very Positive rating on Steam (85% positive reviews) would not have been possible if the product was not generally good; the problems you mention are solvable with a bit of patience, and they are the exception and not the norm. 

Happy Holidays.,
The FaceRig Team.

All my other programs seems to work fine under Windows 10 and they all use my microphone without problems...

So until they fix this stay away from it because without sound recording this program is pretty much useless.
developer_response:
Hello,

Our dev team tries to answer all users and help them solve their technical issues as fast as possible. I don't know how many developers you'll find are doing that on Steam or any other software forum:)

If you've posted on facerig.com it is possible (not probable, but possible) that we've missed your query since there is a pinned post there saying all technical issues should be posted to the Steam forums since that's where our programmers are most active. However, if we've missed your post please link it so we can take a look as we do want to help.

As for people installing or uninstalling Windows 10, it's not a secret that early adopters of an operating system have always had issues with software/drivers. We never did or will recommend that a user uninstalls or switches OS in order to make FaceRig work. We do, however, require some files and additional info to be able to troubleshoot the issue and it so it doesn't occur anymore. If everyone switches back to their previous version are doing the least desired thing (by us at least) and don't really help us improve the program.  While we do QA ourselves and try to test as many cases, it's impossible to catch EVERY issue. 

Anyway, reply here linking us with your Steam bug report submitted on the Steam forums. (here is how to submit a bug/crash report http://steamcommunity.com/app/274920/discussions/2/34096318703798146/)

Excellent funny little software, unless you have a beard. A manly beard that is! Not those hipster skin warmers that kids today speak as a "beard", but a true "I was vacationing with Tom Hanks in a deserted island" type of beards. Stache and everything! The kinda face hair that Sgt. Maj. John Sixta would have a hissy fit meltdown when he would see it, because this face haven't been policed in a looooong time... Maybe trimmed a little bit... occasionally.
But a long story short: Good software!

It's less like looking into a mirror than it is like watching a monkey trying to mimic your expressions, but FaceRig has significantly improved in its functionality since its official release in July. Many of these models are fantastic in their capacity to display highly-expressive emotion properly and on time, such as Zyraxes (R), which appears to look stoned half the time when I use him. In addition, they're collaborating with the developers of games I appreciate (such as Starbound; I wouldn't have purchased FaceRig if I didn't instantly fall in love with the Floran model), and revolutionary experimental software (Live2D), the former of which is offered for free.

FaceRig has given me a significant amount of enjoyment through Skype shenanigans, among other things, and was well worth the $15 price. I'm not sure I can recommend it for business use, given that it's still highly unrefined, however, with the sheer number of currently available avatars, the potential for more to be released through the Steam Workshop and for free, and the quality improvements of existing avatars FaceRig has implemented since its appearance on Steam, it continues to explode with potential. Currently the best publicly available facial-recognition software, FaceRig is worth buying just to see Zyraxes twirling a highly-suggestive alien antennae attached to his tongue as he reacts with you to the display.

PS: I do hope they avoid rigging real people. Their Pewdieverse DLC was a horrible idea, and although that may have been mostly due to the average Steam user's "slightly" negative impression of PewDiePie, I feel the concept itself is bad. FaceRig seems to model its best characters after works of fiction and fantasy (such as TF2), and I would hate to see it begin adding celebrities such as Brad Pitt. If that were the case, it would be targetting a very specific audience not commonly found on Steam... God forbid they add other youtubers. Thanks for reading!

developer_response: Hi, have you checked if your PC meets the minimum requirement in order for FaceRig to work? I would suggest to verify cache integrity like this: Please right click FaceRig in the software list - properties - local files - verify cache integrity. Let it run then try again FaceRig. If you are able to get to launch- then go to settings (the three cogwheels) then change the Render Options -Render Api to DX11 and try FaceRig. If the issue persists please take a look at this thread http://steamcommunity.com/app/274920/discussions/2/34096318703798146/.

developer_response:
That error means you 
a)are running FaceRig on a PC that does not have the minimum requirements  (these are listed on the Steam store page) 
b)haven't updated your drivers in quite a while. We recommend updating your drivers to the latest version from you GPU's manufacturer website

If, however, you have another GPU (video card) other than the one you are currently using (perhaps you are using the integrated GPU and have a dedicated one as well) we recommend you use that one.

review:
You don't even need to use this software for that long to know that this app is utter crap.

Voice recongnition and configuration... crap. It's only really mouthing half what you are saying and mumbling on it's own afterwards. 

Face matching... crap. If you notice, the eyes are very droopy and for some characters, they don't even look at you when you are staring at the camera. So bad eye contact configuration as well. 

Character customization... is very inconveniant and limited. The most you can do with character creation is honestly, just color the character and give it some props here and there. No costume selection or anything like that though if you were hoping that would be in the program. (not that I did but just something I thought you should know)

There are some props you can use to use as a "costume" like hats and glasses. I tried putting my character on with glasses and why the hell did they spawn it in between the nape of her neck... why were they trying to waste my time with that? What's worse is that they have HAIR as part of the props. 

"Oh you want bangs for your character? Here you go! But we're going to make it even more difficult for you by spawning it in the middle of the air and when you try to actually have it connect with the rest of her, it'll look like the most unnatural thing ever. Have fun." 

Just... f- you!


Like seriously, I thought this would be a fun little program to use to do vlogs with instead of having people see my actual face but facerig is an incredibly flawed program. Honestly, if you are thinking of buying this app for "fun" don't. It's more fustrating that fun. And unless facerig decides to fix these problems, I will continue to give them a solid thumbs down.
developer_response:
Hello,

FaceRig is a software aimed at entertainment and content creators alike. Thus, we offer quite a bit of customization options to improve your exeprience and that of your fans/viewers.

"Voice recognition" is quite good if you'll take a look at this video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6PYDCegwUcA it just needs a bit of tweaking to work perfectly with your microphone as there are inherent delays and background noises that need filtering (these differ from hardware to hardware and thus cannot be done automatically)

While the default calibration recognizes a wide variety of facial types and features, being a 2D sensor (just your webcam) recognition is requires a bit of finetuning that can be very easily done. Here is a guide. Just go to whichever face part is acting up for you and look at how to tweak the sliders for it :) http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=315322209

The props offer the user the possibility to attach them to a various amount of bones. Which bone you attach them to dictates which part of the body they will move with (depending on the prop you will want a different body part, moustache-mouth, hat->head, piercing-many parts!). So the initial placement may not be ideal for ALL of the bones but we've optimized it for a few base bones like the Head bone. Optimizing every prop for every single bone in every avatar is possible but would/will take time and, in some cases it might even be pointless since some of our users really like placing props in very unusual ways to express creativity (which we absolutely LOVE). Here is a show presentation of props and how to attach them https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j9yoDPybyKE Tweaking around with the bone and sliders will help place the prop exactly where you want it to be.

Oh and if you select the CUSTOM skin that most avatars have, you will also notice that you can change A LOT more. Like add a skin to the avatar's surfaces (skin/fur/clothes etc)

The software is made in a way that it will allow the maximum amount of customization for the features it has. It's meant to tickle your creative bone and offer you the possibility of doing fun, expressive things with it.

Additionally we provide support for ALL of these features by having a team that's active on the Steam forums (how many other devs do that, really now?) so you can drop by and ask us stuff any time you wish. Drop by and make a suggestion of how to improve a feature and we'll take it into consideration!

Even if the programme is well made, very funny and prety easy to understand I can't recommend this programme for one and only one reason, the cpu usage. I love how in their descriptiopn they say you can use it for every usage, skype, video and streaming etc,

An average game use about 9cpu.( Heroes of the storm, LoL, Cs:go)
OBS which is my streaming programme take about 21 cpu with my overlay and stuff.( Yes streaming does need a good comp).
But FACERIG take an average of 35 cpu. Like really. I tryed lowering the resolution to the minimum, dropping every fps including looping to 20 which is lower then the minimum to have a decent working and still I can only get it down to 26cpu.

I have a built copmputer worth of 1300$ bought 4 month ago and with streaming, a normal game open and facerig I hit 100% cpu usage and I start lagging. Without streaming and game open JUST facerig I hit about 50% cpu usage.

So if you want to have fun alone with funny face it can be worth 10$. But forget about taking it to ANY public level or your computer wont be able to run it.

There are some basic things this program doesnt allow for sadly. Like shaking your head yes or no is not really a possibility. The lips seem to have about 3 states of stretched and 6 states of openess, with a kissy position. This sadly is not really good enough to look like your talking. When i spoke most the time the characters lips dont even move. A great concept poorly carried out. Regrettable.
developer_response:
Most of the issue you are listing are caused by either:
- using an animation atomics avatar (A overlay on the portrait)  without enabling and configuring audio based lipsync or
- not using   Free-Form retargeting avatars at all (those with an R overlay on their portrait) :)

Here are some videos from YouTube, with people using Animation Atomics avatars correctly :

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iUQSHZ4lmxY
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xB7qbarr8F0

The program starts by default with the Basic UI, which has only 10 buttons in its top bar. To get to the Advanced UI  (from the Basic UI)  you need to press the Advanced Ui button which is  last button on the far right in the top bar.

review: Incognito simulator 2015.
Meh. Dissapointed at what it really is and how it works (hint: not that good).

So much better now that you can wear glasses with it, but it still doesn't track eyes correctly. Lips aren't synced as well as I would like them, but that could be my cams fault. Doesn't work well with dark rooms and cams that function bad in dark rooms, so I suggest having a good quality cam if you plan to purchase this. Ran into a few hiccups like missing avatars and files but a simple verify cache seemed to have found the problem.

Overall this is such an amazing program, especially for streamers who hate to live cam and people who just like to troll others on skype and whatnot. The new Natsuko character really needs color options for her clothing and hair, because I simply adore her and wish to customize her to look like me lol. I bought this 2 days before it went on sale. I missed out on saving 4 dollars. GOD DAMN IT.

It runs like shit on my laptop (as expected, so that's obviously my own fault), but it functions perfectly fine and it's exactly what it offers on the tin. Fun to play around with and great for creeping out your friends over skype. Couldn't ask for much more than that.

11/10, because much like the amps in Spinal Tap, this goes to 11.

Let me make this simple... you want this.  You know you do.  You've probably been watching it for awhile, or seen a few videos here and there... but there's this nagging thought in your head.  "What if it sucks" it whispers... or "You'll never use this for anything..."  Kick that little ball of doubt in the nards, take it's lunch money, and buy this software.

Heck... I liked it enough after 5 minutes to buy all the DLC.  Despite my existing webcam working fine with it, I went out and upgraded that just to get a bit more fidelity out of the facial recognition.  (Went from a Logitech Quickcam Deluxe to a cheap c270, just because it had a better sensor)  Have I made any videos with it?  A few.  Have I enjoyed messing around with it?  Yeah!  Is it worth full price?  It's worth double that and more IMHO, and the devs and community are awesome.

So crank it up to 11.  Be awesome.

Very nice tool to use every now and again, or to just mess around in.  Has really good tracking, considering my very low fps built-in camera, and my glasses.  A bit twitchy, but that's on my end.  Overall really well made!
This is just so amazing. Though, you may find yourself spending a good amount of time just goofing around with it and making crazy faces. But what's wrong with that? c:

review: Brilliant. Just Brilliant.
I think it is a really cool product.
I really had high expectations for this application. But I was quite dissapointed with the face recognition. Overall, I would not really buy this application due to its price.

It isn't perfect, but it is REALLY fun. It will run well even on devices below the required specs.

My specs:
Intel i7-2630QM CPU @ 2.00GB
8.00Gb RAM
1366x768 60 Hz
480p camera
I get about 37 Fps, with no lag. Make sure to have a lot of light on your face, it doesn't work well in low light. Even a phone LED light helps.

It makes Skype hilarious, and its well worth the $14.99. The anthropomorphic characters seem to work the best.

If your camera isn't working (black screen), try:  within FaceRig going into the Advanced UI --> general options -> devices -> there in that list re-select the right webcam, even if it is already selected, and then press refresh.

Overall, I'd give it a 8.9/10. being able to use it over skype makes it even better, and its cool to be able to transform into an anthro wolf, tiger, doge, TF2 character, or one of the other dozens of characters with customization.
