WARNING DO NOT BUY THIS !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I bought this product to use in my twitch streams however little did i know or anyone that probably has tried to use this in the background while running other applications that this program uses 60%-99% of your CPU which has caused my pc to crash at times. Even on low settings at lowest resolution this still shoots CPU usage to 90%.
PC specs 
- AMD FX 8120 eight core processor 3.1ghz
- 12g ram
- nvidia geforce gtx 760 4038mb

Used this product for 2-3 days and finally realized why my pc was acting up, which this program was the cause. 
my recommendation is to wait until its fully optimized. 

Asked for a refund and was denied.
developer_response:
Hello DB,

You can configure the program to use less CPU, by using settings that have nothing to do with the resolution ( rendering in a lower resolution mostly affects GPU occupancy, not the CPU occupancy) . 
We have ran FaceRig on systems similar to yours and we definitely did not get typical CPU usages of 60% to 99% if the running programs were properly configured. Please make a post in  the Bugs and Troubleshooting forum about this so that on Monday, when the programmers will be back in the office, together we will sort out why it behaves like this on your system, and what settings are optimal for you. :D 

In the mean-time here's what you can try: 
You can limit the fps of the main loop from the default of 60 to a more manageable 30. 
Furthermore make sure your webcam is not providing video feed at an excessive resolution ( like 1080p) as  720p or even 480p should be plenty  for face-tracking, anything above that is just extra work for the CPU.
Also make sure you are running in dx11 mode ( dx9 mode does eat significantly more CPU)
You are maybe using the experimental "nextversion" branch, where we specifically warn you that on "face lost" events , the cpu usage will spike. If that is the casejust roll back to the default branch if you do not want to deal with experimental implementations :)


At any rate, It is best to make a thread on the support forum where you can explain the issue in detail and we can provide solutions and do the needed detective work to figure out why it takes 99% on a 8 core cpu
:)  Regarding the refunds policy : that's 100% handled by Valve/Steam, not by us :).

review: LAGS AND MOVES SLOW WASTE OF MONEY
This is awesome
It's such a cool premise. I wanted badly to like this, but it loses tracking all the time, and the lip sync is awful. Even my 2-year-old niece knew something was amiss.
developer_response:
Hello IA

Both these issues are most likely caused by how you have configured your visual and audio tracking set-up.  Drop by the forum or send us a recorded face-cam feed, we'll analyse it and show how how to do it properly so you get near perfect lip-sync and consistent tracking :)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iUQSHZ4lmxY

Hopefully you are not among  the folks who consider something like this
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=483680188
to be an  ideal lighting set-up for image based face tracking  :)

Incidentally in the screenshots section, in about one in six screenshots that show the users we see very poorly configured light set-ups ( for image-based motion capture), which is suspiciously close to the disapproval/approval rating of the Steam reviews, so is hard not to draw a parallel :) . 

We trust that the problems that most of the disappointed users are facing when using FaceRig stem from the fact that they do not truly try and to "get" how image-based tracking and sound based tracking works and also have no desire to drop by the Steam FaceRig support forums to learn how to optimally set up their capture space.

developer_response:
Hello polyvoz

Is your little laptop that almost could, above the listed minimal requirements for CPU and GPU?

If the answer is yes then probably is a settings issue that you can tweak and after that FaceRig will work smoothly, so  please drop by the FaceRig Steam bugs and troubleshooting forum and make a thread so we can figure it out.  
For instance most folks do not realize that on many laptops with inexpensive microphones  Windows comes configured by default with lag inducing sounds effects - such as digital noise reduction-  already activated, and those can add about 0.2 seconds of input audio lag before the sound even reaches FaceRig. This will of course mess with the audio based lipsync.  Also most folks do not realize that many laptops have very poor cooling, as as soon as their GPU and CPU start actually being used, they overheat and soon after they get auto down clocked, so their real performance in those cases is only a fragment of what is written " on paper").


If the laptop is indeed below the listed minimum specs then ... yes hardware below the minimal requirements will perform sub-par :) .

developer_response:
This is what users have been making with FaceRig, even from back in 2014.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iUQSHZ4lmxY

We have plenty more examples of well executed movies from users on YouTube. We do not consider the above example  poor lipsync.

We trust what has happened in your case was either one or more of the following : 

1. Most likely you did not activate sound-based lipsync at all.
2. You did activate it but didn't calibrate correctly the background noise gate.
3. You did not deactivate lag inducing microphone effects from the windows microphone effects ( such as Acoustic noise cancellation or digital noise reduction that add up to 0.2 seconds of  audio lag to an user's microphone before the sound even reaches FaceRig.).
4. You did not use the outgoing audio delay slider to compensate for syncing issues in the output audio stream or exported movies.

developer_response:
It DOES support laptop use provided that:

- the laptop is above the listed minimum specs (CPU and GPU) 
- you remember to set it to run in high performance mode and set it to use  the dedicated GPU.

It is true it does not run smoothly with its default settings on entry-level under-powered ultra thin devices that look slick but have poorly engineered cooling as those down-clock their CPU and GPU almost immediately once you actually start using them for anything other than web-browsing watching a movie or using office suites. But this is also true for many games, not just FaceRig. For those cases you will have to dial down the graphic settings in FaceRig.

developer_response:
Hello Googles,

Sorry to hear about this. We just wished you had at least attempted to make a post on the bug forum and given us a chance to offer you support before deciding to give up on the program  (which is still in Early Access)  :)  . 

We have recently added a new unified virtual webcam driver, to replace the two old ones that we were using before ( for 32 bit and 64 bit apps) .  This reduces ( not increases) the number of additional installs , plus the new one one is compatible with more browsers, more chat apps and with the upcoming windows 10.  

It was developed by a specialized company ( not us) , Adoriasoft LLC, who has developed virtual drivers before. It has spent time in their QA lab (both alone and as part of FaceRig) to test against possible problems before being deployed publicly.

Many of our users on Steam also have manually installed it and tested it a few days ahead of wide scale deployment, and have confirmed to us that it works.    

In the last 20 hours, after wide scale deployment , we have learned that on few cases (total of 4 signalled to us so far, you included) , users (definitely not all, but probably more than 4) after installing this new driver had to plug/unplug their physical webcams or, in the case of integrated ones, enable/disable them from the device manager so that they re-gain their status as default webcams. That's the problem you are most likely experiencing. 

As a side effect, if the FaceRig program starts and does not find a proper real webcam video feed, it temporarily uses up more cpu trying to find your face on whatever input feed it receives. That behaviour is caused by the tracking library, which is also not developed by us, but licensed from ULSee Inc, a company with a reputable pedigree in the field of computer vision.  

To bypass that issue you can simply disable the face tracking from the top menu setting or from the program launcher settings (which you can access before even starting up FaceRig - we have built such a launcher particularly thinking ahead about situations like these, where you need to access the settings from outside the program) until you can sort out  the webcam settings within the program, so your CPU is not used by the tracking library in the interim.  

If your system specs are close to the minimal ones, then yes when you face is not being tracked and  the tracking library is in "seek face" mode, that can demand quite a lot from your CPU, and it can cause it to be sluggish, especially if it is on the low-side performance wise. 
We will look into ways of further limiting that effect. At any rate, any program by itself, even if it demands a lot of CPU power,  should not be able to just fry a system, unless that system has a defective cooling or is overclocked. 

We apologise for the inconvenience this has caused :)
There are no "million" plugins involved.
All the parts of the program are developed by competent developers, and tested before they even reach a single user on Steam. However bugs can still slip by. It is part of a normal Beta/Early Access process.


Regards
The FaceRig team :)

An interesting piece of software to say the least.  A lot of fun, managed to prank my girlfriend with it.  We both had a good laugh as I turned from a cheezeburger into a belgian maid.

What is facerig? It's a mocap (motion capture) system for webcams, which replaces, in pretty close to real time, your face with a 3D animated model instead.

Overall, it's a very good program. The models are mostly high quality, the customization options are fairly respectable and so on. There are a few issues, such as lip synching which assumes you have a brittish accent and tends to add extra syllables that aren't actually pronounced. Another minor issue is it has problems tracking any sort of quick motions or motions which go past a fairly restrictive range of movement and it'll take a second or three to re-synch.

As a whole, however, for $10, it's remarkably high quality. Many times over higher quality than it has any right to be for that cost, actually. It's fun, effective, and will generate some pretty fun conversations at the very least.

A lot of the features have yet to be implemented, so keep in mind that this is basically beta software, yet higher quality than most full releases.

The difference between the standard version and the pro version, is simply that the pro version lets you use it for professional use (ie: you get paid for such). Like you could use it to stream or for youtube if you aren't getting paid for your content with the standard version, but if you want to use it for things that generate revinue, then you have to pay a bit more.

A studio version will be available next year supposedly which makes it actually useful for generating revinue, however, so I'd suggest holding out for that. In theory, the studio version will allow for recording animations, then exporting the animation files into programs like Maya to tidy up the animation curves and make it look professional, which would make it the cheapest quality motion capture option out there, really. Well, short of "free" stuff which largely sucks, to be blunt.

For those with modeling experience, you don't technically need to own the program to build a model and rig it for use in facerig, and you can even sell your models without owning the software, but you wouldn't be able to test to verify that it works properly with facerig, so make of that as you will. It's still a nice policy, though.

For the moment, facerig has some issues, but promises to be updated with patches to add new features and tighten up the quality of the features that exist, and that's well worth looking into.

As a whole, it works fairly well. It's not the highest quality motion capture program out there, but considering those run into the thousands of dollars, and this is $10 and works pretty much out of the box almost with only a few setting tweaks which are easy to make, it's a good option for the average person, and those with 3D design experience will find it even more useful since you can add your own models in as well.
-------------------
June 18th, 2015 update:

A few new features have been added since this review was added originally, and an updated GUI has been thrown in as well. It's a little more confusing than before, but a fair bit more powerful in terms of what you can do with it. The average user will probably find themselves playing with settings for an hour or more when they first start out before getting it to do exactly what they want, but once you've got it down, it's not that bad.

The ability to record videos has been added, and these are exported as .webm files. With a fair bit of tinkering, I was able to get facerig to work well enough for youtube. Another nice benefit is that the audio files are saved separately as well as .mp3's so you can edit the audio individually in something like soundforge. Premiere will need a bit of help to figure out what to do with .webm's though.

If you run into technical problems, feel free to ask them on the steam forum! I've had a few issues I've run into and every time I've asked, within 12 hours I had a very detailed and well-explained answer, with full follow-up, not just copy/pasting from a text file. Like they actually took the time to understand the issues I had and did actual troubleshooting. Seriously, I haven't seen a company with customer service this good before. They are literally #1 by far in this department, so that's a major bonus in their favour!

There is currently an issue with the recording aspect where slower computers (my poor piece of junk for example =P ) can run into a video/audio desync. There's not much that can be done to fix this as of this update, short of re-recording the clip again, but when I ran into the issue I was given a list of ways to mitigate the issue, and that they're aware of this issue and a patch fix is in the works. There's definitely continually updated support, so it will keep on getting better with time!

Again, this is not the greatest motion capture software in the business - but anything better out there costs $30,000 for the liscence, so that should give you an idea of what you're looking at. For $10, there's really no way to argue that this is a bad deal. And it's vastly better than whatever similar program you probably had come bundled with your webcam, because there really is no comparision between them in terms of quality.

developer_response:
Hello  Sintful1,

If we are to talk specifically about the audio based lipsync, we trust your experience is most likely related to not knowing (or mis-using) the lip-sync options put at your disposal.

If the sound is properly routed through FaceRig and a sound delay setting is customized, quite good results can be obtained in regard to audio-based lipsync (user video links below).
 
We have had users who have been able to create lipsync videos that are a lot more than just decent, and it is important to remember these are completely automated results generated by analysing the input sound in real time, without any touch-ups done manually by animators like they do in movies and games.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iUQSHZ4lmxY
https://youtu.be/DnqD1sip1Vw?t=1m4s
https://youtu.be/N5eXcWN6MKA
https://youtu.be/0I1jbQcWa3s?t=19s ( this last one is actually created by us when facering was not even released yet, by running a saved input facecam video & audio  received from one of our amazing users who also writes poetry.) 

We trust there are very few (if any) automated sound based lipsync systems out there that work this well in real time ( on consumer level hardware and at consumer level prices)  without manual user intervention on the output data.

developer_response:
I'm pretty sure it is a misunderstanding here, as the new EULA actually lowered the restrictions for monetising on YouTube/Twitch, not raised them, so you can use it more freely. 

The previous rules were more restrictive in regard to monetization (by monetization we mean making money off the content you generate with FaceRig) monetization on Twitch/YouTube was only possible with the Pro upgrade, while now, is also possible with the basic version as long as your revenue from those sources is under a certain monthly threshold).

Ok, so this review will cover the basics on what you will find, like, not like, etc. Be in mind this review is set for when the software is still being updated, i will try and also cover what new comes to it.


Ok so first off before you buy this be warned, it is still in development as stated on the software page, I did expect some bugs and glitches, maybe even some crashes but I haven't got one yet, only bugs and glitches.


[h1]Downloading the software[/h1]
Once you buy the software, you will have probably the longest first time setup list on steam yet. This will download things such as some players and a few other things. [i]I still haven't figured out two of the downloads and their purpose.[/i] After the first time setup, it is a really fast start up, It only took me about 30 seconds to load and for it to give a character to me.

[h1]Inside the software/Using the camera for motion[/h1]

Ok, I will say 1 thing I am upset with, is that the demo they gave on the page, for cameras such as a built in Laptop one, or one simular to it, does not work well with this software. They showed smooth usage of the software no lag nothing. Granted i just stated earlier that this was still being worked on and is early access, but that irritated me a little.

Now when you load up an avatar you want to use these are some of the issues you will see in the program.

[b]Laggy video

Issues with eye, tongue, and head movment

Must have constant eye contact with computer camera, or it loses focus[/b]

After those issues I know some people are going to say either, "You're lying that doesn't happen!" or "Ok, I think I might pass on buying this."

Be in mind these are issues [b]I[/b] have had, I am not saying multiple people had the same issues with this.


[h1]Using this on Skype, Google Hangouts, etc.[/h1]
Now, I have not delved into this part of the program yet, from what I've seen in the videos it looks promising. I have a friend that has tried it on Skype, but never could figure out how to do it, so there may be some issues figuring that out.
If I can figure it out I think I could surprise a few of my friends with it :/.


[h1]Things I would like to see added/updated[/h1]

What I would like to see wth this is more character skins, currently there are only a few, just in different forms, to list a few there are I believe 2 anime characters, a space commander, a dragon, an anthro wolf, a regular wolf, and elvish princess along with a few others. Now that might be a lot for some people, but it really doesn't bring out a level of selection, I want to be like "Wow there's a lot to choose from, I can be this... NO this, no this, no this, no this uugh I don't know what to choose." But i know it will be years before that.. reaction, will happen.

I also want to see more of a community for this, This is not really known to the world or many places at all, the more of a community that the makers have the more helpful info to fix, bugs/crashes/glitches/freezes etc.

I would also love to see this due to as I said earlier, the program doesn't work really well on laptops or built in cameras. I would love to see an update that fixes that to where I don't have to keep total eye contact with the camera, where I can turn my head completely away from the camera and it still detect me.


[h1]Final Verdict/Rating[/h1]

The program is very good, I would recommend buying it due to there is a lot currently, but as far as characters go, it's limited.
Would I recommend you get this for the main price? Yes!... For something like this, a mear $10-20 is a steal.

In all, I give this a 9.2/10

[u]I will update this review when new updates for the program come around.[/u]

review: Really nice must get
The coolest idea that will never work.

I can not get the tracking to work, or the lip-syncing. It vibrates and when I hit "Reset Tracking" and I stay still and have a normal expression, it won't load. It stays still until I move my head, and then it spazzes out. I'm disappointed, but if there is a solution, I would love to know

loaded one time then it never worked again. 
5/10

While it is still in deveolopement, it's actually really nice and works well, though you will find yourself readjusting the tracker often. It also has a little trouble with tracking your eyes and how closed they are, but you have the option to turn off eye tracking. If you really want to be a 3D avatar on camera, then get it. Otherwise, don't because that's the sole purpose of this program.

I totally can't deny that FaceRig is a fun tool and it works perfectly with my webcam. It's quite fun to use your webcam and drop some silly avatar there that follows your face and does some lipsync when you talk. But that's about it.

When looking at practical and long-term use I can't really see any use for this tool at all. I tried to see how it looks with twitch and honestly it really looks silly and unproffessional. Not to mention that the ‚Ç¨10 license has some holes when it comes to public broadcasting and monetesation (you need the 'DLC' package for that).

Using FaceRig with Skype when you call your friends and family overseas would be fun as well, but after one or two calls with each and every avatar I wouldn't use it anymore and instead drop my own face there.

I do have to comment on the developer that he surely supports FaceRig very well. He helped me out with some issues I had and he immediately knew where the issue I had came from. BIG THANKS there!

Bottom line, if you're in for pranks and use the 'silly avatars' from FaceRig to call friends and family overseas and such, then FaceRig is for you. But sadly I made the mistake not to realize it up front and wasted my money on buying it. Perhaps I'm just 'too old' to play this kind of pranks on Skype...

I've been messing around with this for a while more now, and revised my list.

+ Wide selection of characters available
+ Easy to use tools
+ Very customisable
+ People with small eyes can use this :)

- Resetting the face tracking does not always fix it (for me)
- Tracking is not 100% accurate yet

I personally love this program, however if you want to make movies I don't recommend it, the models can be very stiff and insconsistant at times. On Skype this is fun to use; changing characters and messing around with your friends. Since this is still in development, there is most likely going to be very good improvements in the future. If you seek this for animation purposes, wait a few updates. If you want this for a representation of what future technology can do, buy it.

review: This overall is pretty fun. The new updates make it better. I wish that the loading time where better, but besides that it is fun. If you have little kids I think they will like Facerig.

This game shows great potential. It used to work perfect for me in earlier development. Very responsive movement and lip synchronisation. Even with my glasses it worked just fine. Blinking and eye detection however was unresponsive due to this.

After much more development, I decided to return to the game to find it cannot detect my face anymore. I tried removing my glasses and adjusting lights and camera angle. My camera is in full working condition with exceptional quality. Yet it still cannot detect my face and one one occassion it managed to for about a minute with appaulingly unresponsive movement.

It's such a shame that the face tracker doesn't seem to work anymore, this software has so much potential but it has failed to prove that. I now only regret buying this software and cannot reccommend it due to its unstability and face recognition.
So good that Apple will likely buy it for face time.

review: wont let me play it says there is an error code called c0000135
developer_response:
Hi,

Please follow up on this thread: 
http://steamcommunity.com/app/274920/discussions/2/613935404221058577/#c34096318931030378 or this one: http://steamcommunity.com/app/274920/discussions/2/616198623975827188/

It is highly possible that the redistributables (VS2010 or VS2008) did not install correctly so I suggest re-installing them. Just go to <steamInstallDir>\SteamApps\common\FaceRig\_CommonRedist\ to find them.

Also, you should make sure that the AV installed on your system (if any) is not blocking FaceRig or did not let the full installation (there have been reports of FaceRig.exe missing from the install directory). Check by browsing to <steamInstallDir>\SteamApps\common\FaceRig\Bin\FaceRig.exe.

I would also suggest verifying data integrity (from Steam, go to FaceRig, right click, go to Properties, go to LOCAL FILES tab then click on VERIFY INTEGRITY OF APPLICATION FILES).

Have you ever stared stupidly into the mirror, mugging at yourself?  No?  Just me, then?

Ahem.  Okay, well, you should really try it sometime.  This is software that allows you to turn a webcam and a computer into a kind of magical mask.  You can turn yourself into demons and angels, and marvel as they follow your every move.  It feels really lame to say this, but it is a really bewitching effect.  

It is a cheap fix, and will keep kids entertained for a while, too. My friend's daughter spent hours just adjusting her colors. 

But I really couldn't honstly tell you what it is for...  For most of us, it is pointless software, but it is remarkably fun for as cheap as it is.  

Note that this is pre-release software, and it gets a little angsty sometimes.  It only recently started working with Google Hangouts, for instance.  The developers seem to be putting quite a bit of work into it, still, though, so it might change quite a bit after I post this review.

Why does Steam say I have 74 hours on this?

Pro's
- See's your face.
- Does track.
Con's
- You need an expensive camera with over 30fps
- You need at least 720p camera
- The tracking is really, Realy bad.
- Lip Syncing is horrible
- The Characters are VERY limited.
developer_response:
You do NOT need an expensive camera in order for FaceRig tracking to work properly.
We've personally tested it with a wide range of webcams (from the Logitech c920 to cheap no-brand Chinese webcams.)
Cheap webcams are able to get 30 fps with no problem nowadays. Tracking will work with less than that, but higher fps does mean better tracking quality.
Your camera does NOT need to be 720p for tracking to work properly. It is, however, preferred that you have decent lighting (so that the tracker can SEE your face)
While it is still in development, as most features, lip sync works pretty well. If you calibrate your sound settings to adjust the noise level in your environment and set a slight delay between the sound and the lip movements (very small delay - miliseconds), that significantly improves your results. See this video for a sample of what can be achieved with the lip sync feature :) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iUQSHZ4lmxY

developer_response:
Hello,

To answer your question: no, you will not be required to pay anything extra for the Classic version of FaceRig when it is officially released or at a later date. Anything you buy in Beta (DLCs/Pro Upgrade) will also transfer to live version.

As for the bugs, I'd like to ask you to please make a post  on our Bugs&Troubleshooting discussion boards http://steamcommunity.com/app/274920/discussions/2/ about the issue of the colors being slightly off.

For the blurriness issue, if you are using DX11, this issue might be already solved in our "nextversion" branch update. 

How to get this "nextversion" : 
-Open Steam Client. Go to Library -> Software 
-Right mouse click on FaceRig -> Properties 
-Go to BETAS tab, click in the "Select the beta you would like to opt into:" drop down, select "nextversion" 
-Close window. The FaceRig program will update to the "nextversion" branch.

If this doesn't solve the issue, please include it in your post on our discussion boards.

Thank you for using FaceRig and helping us make it better for everyone!

developer_response:
The review is wrong is assuming it does not work with Flash-based solutions.

Here is a user made tutorial  video about using it directly on Chatroulette.

True , It does not always work in Firefox ( the process for granting firefox access to a DirectShow based virtual webcam is more problematic)  but so far it seems that it does work in Chrome (for most of our users anyway).

The developers have a great concept.

The application could be used to have fun with friends and family over Skype or for doing a business webinar. Imagine being able to conduct webinars using your own business avatar that has been custom built and branded. The novelty would eventually wear off but for right now it is startlingly good.

As of this writing, it's still in beta. I just ran some quick tests to see if it would work well for students and teachers.

The only show-stopper for actually using it in a business environment would be that the tracking needs to be a little faster for speech (it's hard to see the lips moving if you talk at normal speed). This probably just requires the developers to nail down sensativity to lip movement.

If you like the idea and see a purpose for it, pick it up. This one is worth supporting in Early Release. And to the developers, keep up the great work. You may have an absolute gem on your hands once everything is tweaked and perfected.

Fun software to use. Simple to use and fairly effective. I use a low quality and low fps camera (8-9 fps). My lighting conditions are also often far from ideal. Although the conditions are bad, FaceRig does an admirable job of accurately tracking my movements. I have had very few problems with it.
While I used FaceRig, I could hardly tell that it was still in Beta.
There are also optional fixes for some problems you might encounter that you can enable in the settings if you encounter that problem. (eg. Eyes not opening)
If you are thinking of getting FaceRig, you should get it. It is worth every cent.

review: Great Software, I Am having a problem though when I launch it the charector has a brown face and starts lagging

I'm just a little bit torn, but I don't want to give the wrong idea, so let me explain.

This is really a very polished and useable product, and I think most people, depending upon their reasons for buying it, will be more than satisfied with their purchase.

USABILITY:  The interface is a little daunting at first, with so very many options for tweaking things, but the documentation is very good and the community is pretty good at answering questions.  This interface ends up being one of the big selling parts of this software because the flexibility (once you've figured out what you are doing) is just amazing.  Here's an example:  At first I was having problems with the avatar keeping it's eyes closed, but between the documentation and forums, I was able to fairly quickly diagnose the problem and fix it.  Basically, I set it to blink automatically.

Also, I was having difficulty getting the program to track my movements, but the documentation clearly showed what I needed to do to my webcam to improve that and now it works like a charm.

EXPRESSIVENESS:  This is my one area of complaint, but it's only a partial complaint.  I should state right away that I haven't tried all the avatars, but I have tried a few including all of the Halloween pack.  I basically found the Halloween pack to not meet my expectations.  I recorded a couple of videos, one with the pumpkin and one with the mummy, and neither one really was expressive enough to let my viewers know what I was feeling.  On the other hand, some of the avatars are incredible, most notably the hamburger.  I did a recording of myself playing "I am Bread" and thought that having facerig really made the video better.  Very noticeable expressions and kind of funny too.

I don't have an example of what I was talking about with the Halloween videos because I deleted those, but I can show you what I mean with the other one.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xQF9BkR8LnM&index=2&list=PLV8i2f0l80BnmUYGrynMKOyvVcD8ujWT4

You can do it without the black borders on the edges.  I used the wrong recording size because it was my first attempt and I didn't know what I was doing.  But it just looks amazing.  If you forget all the other crap that's going on in the video and just watch the bread, you can almost read it's lips.  Just amazing.  That did take a little work, though, to sync up the sound with the video.

So overall, I say this is a buy, but don't get your heart necessarily set on one particular avatar unless you've already seen someone else using it.  Some are better than others.

Amazing! This is worth every penny. I have been able to make lots of people laugh at the tongue and odd faces i could make. I will admit though there is a few bugs but that is something you can expect out of a not yet finished product, I cant wait to see how this turns out in the future and if you are considering whether to buy this or not i recommend it,

(I only hit thumbs down because there was no neutral choice)  I cannot say whether or not this is a good program, as I was unable to explore it properly.

   One thing I can recommend to potential buyers is that you do not try to use it with a cheap camera/eye.   As far as I can tell, not actually being a programmer, the program needs an accurate, not hazy, image and keep those quality camera images flowing at, at least, the specified frame rate to reach its proper capacity of accuracy and ability to keep up as shown in the promotional video.   I say this because I tried it with a cheap $5-ish dollar camera/eye and had poor results from it, but I do not think it was necessarily the program's fault.

Long story short, you definitely need a quality camera/eye to use FaceRig right.

All in all, it's fun to use for messing around in skype and omegle. With a clear mic, webcam, anddecent graphic card, the program should run fine.

A complete surprise! 

I enjoy testing betas, and expect a certain number of crashes and blips, but this performed better than expected.   

Well designed, smooth in operation. I've used far more expensive Avatar createsr that don't have the fine details this one has. The avatars are well drawn and responsive. The customisation is extensive, can't wait to see what other options are added. 

Make sure you have adequate lighting when using it, and avoid too much backlighting or FaceRig can't pick up your face's finer movements.  If you wear glasses, take them off if you want the eyes to remain open and responsive.  Take the time to calibrate the face tracker as well. Once all the little details are taken care of, it works exceptionally well. 

Can't wait to see the next generation.

I'm going to be fair here and say, I don't recommend this but I do. Now, that will be a little confusing but let me explain. It's a great piece of software that will, no doubt, be used to to create annonymus characters or faces of youtubers and/or twitch streamers. For this reason, I'll say it's great but now the downside. Simply put, it's still in its early phase and because of this, it has its flaws and tbh, not being able to use the software effectively because you have small eyes is a little bit of shame (personal experience *Sad Face*).

Anyway, long story short, get it if you are confident you can use it effectively, otherwise just take pride in that you know what software a new upcoming youtuber or twitcher is using because it probably not for you.

Pure awesomeness. It's super fun and only $10.

Also, for internet personalities, you can spend $40 more to use is commercially, and monetize it on YouTube, Twitch, etc. For Let's Players or Vloggers who don't want to show their real face or who maybe don't have a professional camera and lighting setup in their room, this software is great, as it basically does all your makeup, lighting, and camera work for you. If you know 3D modelling, you can really go crazy with what it can do.

It's not perfect; the lip-syncing right now looks like a 70's kung fu movie, but considering it requires zero setup or calibration and can work with just about any webcam, its face tracking ability is quite impressive. You can't go full insane, but once you get used to it, it's super easy to use and you can be quite expressive with it.

I was disappointed to find that this runs incredibly poorly on my Surface Pro 3 - which usually copes well with other 
semi-intensive games such as Skyrim and Civ V. The games (software?) is not playable on my machine.

I would suggest that you look carefully at the system requirements before purchasing this game - the requirements are rather high.

Heavilly recommended, tracking is smooth and even the lipsync works better than expected. I'm looking forward to user avatars and similar updates.
However, I would suggest adding some graphical settings. I know FaceRig is intended to be semi-photorealistic, but computers with older CPUs are unable to run the software smoothly (there is basically lag). Simple slider to set output render quality would be sufficient (like setting the output to 640x480 instead of 1280x720 etc.). I think some users would appreciate that.

Takes little to no work to set up, and runs fairly well on my mid-range machine. Love the reactions from people I called. Much fun to be had. The lip sync is a tad iffy at the moment with it being sensitive to sound on some cheaper mics, and some characters seem to respond to certain movements better than others. (Hilariously so, I may add) Tonnes of settings availible to tweak and fix some of the issues, and its still early access, so its a work in progress, right? Has quite a bit of potential in the long run, and for $10, Its a good buy, Highly reccomend it. Looking foreward to when they smooth out more of the features.

Buy this. Buy this right now. Are you buying it yet? Stop reading this and buy it. Buy the basic version, get hooked, buy the pro version, sell a kidney, throw the proceeds at the Facerig team. This product can and does cure cancer.

FaceRig lets you take on the looks of many unique characters, and move, blink, talk, and rotate to make the experience even more realistic. 

I see that it's about 1/2 and 1/2 on reviews here, saying it doesn't work or what not. I'll try my best to clear this up. Also, this is NOT a troll review, I see too many of those, and it worries me that people won't get an honest review.

Face tracking works about 90% of the time, as long as you set up your camera in a very precise way, either directly below your monitor in the center, or directly above your monitor at eye level in the center. I feel like people are giving this software bad reviews because they do not take the time to adjust the camera to a precise way, (Which to me is a small price to pay to experience this next generation software) and even so, it still is in beta. 


NOTE: I would also like to say that this doesn't require some fancy camera to track your facial expressions and body movements precisely, I have a 10$ 2MP autofocus Logitec camera, and the tracking works perfectly, if, like i said before, the camera is in the right angle. Also, it is very sensitive when it comes to blurriness, if your webcame is blurry it will NOT, let me emphasize, NOT pick up your movement and facial features.

The details in FaceRig are very noticable, the standard backgrounds are fitting with the character models offered, such as a lava baron in a Volcano, dragon on a mountaintop etc... You can also upload your own backrgrounds.

You can surprise your friends on skype, omeagle, and such with facerig, however it is semi-complicated to do so at the moment, but it is still possible, and to me, very much worth it. 

If you are having trouble with facerig and skype, here is a tutorial on how to use skype with facerig
http://steamcommunity.com/app/274920/discussions/0/34096318834663165/

The customization in FaceRig is still under development, but it is still existant. There are also customizations that have already been "grouped" by the facerig team, like instead of Danny (A wolf with clothing) having a brown jacket and a red bandana, there are presets that you can choose to make him have a white bandana and a black jacket.

NOTE: You can upload your own models, but the facerig team has stated that it is almost unususable at the moment, but like i said, still in beta. Also, if you customize the character you are playing as, it will not save when you close out and re-launch FaceRig!

Overall: Great potential, good tracking, and great customization features. 9/10, was very satisfied with the results; I highly reccomend this to anyone with a camera

EDIT: People with glasses, purchase with caution; doesn't track as easily as it does with people without glasses. People with glasses might want to wait until stability improves.

Fursuit joke here, ten outta ten, Internet accolades for groundbreaking dry wit.

In all seriousness I'm pretty impressed with how well this works. I just loaded it up with my basic-ass Logitech C270 webcam and it's up and running out of the box. I didn't have to screw with lighting, heck as I type this it's midnight, the only light is that coming off my monitor, and it STILL works surprisingly well. Have not tried it with glasses yet, though.

As far as the quality of the tracking goes, it's far from professional but probably at least $10 worth of fun to record making silly faces or crank calling your Skype friends. The lip synching can be done either from video or from mic input and automatically prioritizes the video if the mic is currently quiet. There's definitely a bit of lag, you're not going to get it to look as good as the guy narrating the trailer, but the lady silently making the faces seems about on par with my experience. The eye tracking is actually really impressive, it picks up my blinking, squinting, and looking around very well.

The avatars that seem to work best are the hamburger and Octodad, because when you inhabit the more human ones the odd bits of twitchy tracking stand out far more. And then there's the nightmarishly unappealing furry avatars, this coming from a guy who's OK with furries. Honestly, my biggest gripe about the program at this point is that it doesn't seem to save ANY of the configurations on exit presently. It also has to re-register your neutral face pose anytime it loses a lock on you, resulting in some very skewed neutral expressions sometimes.

This is absolutely fantastic, recommend it to everyone. 
Easy to master, initial set of avatars is sufficient, and since the program emulates a webcam it will integrate with virtually every piece of software. 
Even though in beta, no crashes so far, and a Ton-load of instant fun: when my daughter skyped she went: Dad, there's no video.. Respons: wait, I know what's wrong and I'll fix it. And then she was greeted by Fluffo - and melted :)
You can surprise anyone with this - and have some laughs.

There are a few area's of improvement, logical since it's beta, it will be interesting to see how these are adressed:
- props need manual adjustment before they are correctly in place - not everyone is familiar with 3D coordinates.
  (the viking helmet looks great on Fluffo though :) )
- glasses interfere with the detection of the eyes. (Ofcourse this is a challenge to all face-tracking software) 
- I had to use Morphvox pro to change the voice to something fitting for Fluffo. 
- shoulder activity can not be turned on. In stead, when clicking on the corresponding checkbox, the dialog jumped a number of pixels down. Let's hope that gets fixed soon.

But all in all, this piece of software may well become a very big hit - and rightfully so.
Kudo's to the inventors.

Additionally, the software is great and easy to use- it takes the place of a camera so when you have any application that uses video feed you can use that "camera" instead to call people on skype, record video, so on and so forth.

One of the biggest complaints I have is the watermark on the software- I understand that I purchased the normal version but I did pay money for it and as shallow of a complaint as it is, when I chat with my friends I don't want a watermark giving away my "secret" before I choose to. I hope the developers choose to remove this but I hightly doubt they will. Keep in mind that you can purchase the license software as well and the watermark will still be there.

Other than that, the customization is surprisingly simple- you're able to create alternate colors of the characters as well as upload 3D models if you so choose. You just have to be sure that you do it right! I hightly recommend this software to anyone who is fond of role playing games and want to utilize Skype's new "free video" functions.

That being said, if you have contacts or not needing glasses at all than the software will perform alright with only a strangely old-styled UI to really put a hamper on things. I actually got a Logitech c270 for my webcam which was the lower end of the series (30 USD) and the camera tracked at an "Ok" efficiency so you won't need to go too high on the webcam market to make this software usable. -- EARLY ACCESS REVIEW! Current review from 13/09/14 --

FaceRig is a program that lets you transcribe your face (over webcam) onto a virtual character on-screen.
It works well in the sense that it works well on any webcam. I have a fairly low-end Logitech C270, which is the benchmark to low-mid level webcams, and it works fine. Only very occasionally have I had weird glitches, like the following: 

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=312617743 

But they are quickly reset and a more high-end webcam with a better refresh rate shouldn't suffer from this.
As shown in the screenshot, I have noticed a few problems with eyelid tracking, in the sense that one of the eyes either never blinks or appears to be half open, giving your character a "derpy" look. I don't hold this against the software however as it makes the characters look cute.

Speaking of characters, they have a wide range of facial expressions but they seem to be incapable of displaying anger. The most you can do to show frustration is to raise your upper lip over your teeth which gives the impression of growling. This is something that the devs could do to add some major credit in my eyes.

It includes the shibe "Doge" as well as a anthropomorphised wolf called Danny, etc. There are tons more and you will probably find at least one that you really like. There has already been some modifiability already into the game but it will be some time before furry 3D modellers find this and start making their own models, but I can see a healthy commission market for this ahead.

There aren't really any things I can compare FaceRig to; it's utterly unique in its position and it has a very good deal of potential for the future. I hope that the dev team will quickly move to eliminate the remaining bugs and then start adding some of the promised features as shown in the trailer,
From 13/09/14 (European dating, obviously) the software already appears to be finished.

Review spoilers: product is Unfinished/early stages.

Face rig is a cute little program that enables avatar based webcam chat. The avatars provided range from the cuteness of doge to the nightmare fuel that is lord burgore the floating cheese burger. The number of avatars avialble along with customization options  of each is a tad limited currently but agian this is an early release product. I'm hoping for steam workshop support as thist will greatly increase the users possible selection of avatars, props and backgrounds. 

Speaking of backgrounds the program comes with a small selection of stock backgrounds for your avatar to inhabit. 
A dark hallway, a scenic green forest, a futuristic backdrop, and a couple more i haven't tried yet. Course you can also just go with your own room but where is the fun in that?

 The avatar lipsyncs with your words and some facial expressions ( depending on the avatar and expression) ,
the tracking, while decent still needs a touch more work to better help the avatar project facial motions made.
for example the midori-chan (anime based) avatar kept doing a weird half scowl half smirk expression when i was in a neutral expression. 

Facerig sports recording and broadcasting features giving it some ambition in hopes to appeal to people wanting to use the program for the production of videos for youtube or other such sites.  It also takes the need to hunt for third party programs 
out of the picture, though only if it caan match the quaility of the ever popular open broadcast, or ffsplit.

I would diffently recommend this program for those looking to spice of their chat experience, specially if it gets steam workshop support which will add a good amount of addintional user based content.

Very cool, and works quite well, especially for beta software. Everything worked as intended. (Though it crashed on close. Not a big deal.) Surprisingly lightweight. I was able to run it on my laptop in battery mode and it didn't even slow down. Definitely would reccomend this. 

Do note, however, that having a decent microphone and video card is important. the video card because this does do quite a bit of fancy-pantsrendering. The microphone because lipsync is largely based on the sound that goes through it.

If you have a complete **** built-in microphone like I do, you can turn up the sensitivity settings in the software, but my reccommendation is that you just get a better mic.

A microphone is not required for mouth movements to work, however, without it, the software will only reproduce broad mouth shapes, and less of the finer ones.

Also, be aware that there IS a watermark on the video, even if you've bought it. A bit of a nuisance, but, hopefully, it will be removed/ made less annoying in future.

FaceRig is only in early access now, so it does have some flaws, but overall, it's truly awesome. It is professionally made face-tracking software that works just by analyzing your face through your webcam, for a ridiculously low price. It's great for literally anything for which you can use your own face, like Skype, vlogs, livestreams, or to keep your anonymity on infamous websites like Omegle and Chatroulette.
What is truly amazing about this is that normally, to achieve the same results as FaceRig achieves, you will need to have either a special suit on or to stick your face full of tracking orbs. FaceRig just analyzes your face through the webcam, and measures all the points of it without all these expensive Hollywood thingos.

The flaws are minor ones, like if you have a bad webcam, the program will likely not work as you would expect. If your face is blurry, it won't be able to recognize you. The same problem occurs when you move too fast, but that is the same reason.
Sometimes, frowning doesn't completely work, but with the reactions on your friends' faces, I doubt you would ever frown anyway.

Things I'm looking forward to: Movement of the arms. If I can have that in here, FaceRig is just perfect.

Possibly the best virtual webcam on the market. You can switch between yourself, the character, or a dual comparison of both. Includes props and virtual backgrounds. Everything is customizable from the characters to the backdrops. 10/10 one of the best apps on steam!

Bought this recently for use on Skype calls, and a few other friends happened to buy it as well.  It's great, we spent a long time playing with the features and trying out all it has to offer, and it has A LOT to offer.  Even though I use this for video calls it also has record functionality and a bunch of other features in case you just want to have fun or mess around, my niece and I spent a while messing around with this software too.

This is basically a piece of face-tracking software that superimposes your facial movements onto a variety of avatars and animal-characters.  There are some realistic fantasy/sci-fi type characters and even some that people who are into 'furry' or 'yiffy' might like, and the graphics are absolutely outstanding.  Not to mention you can actually customize the avatar in a huge number of ways.

The game is in beta still so there's some tweaks to be made but as it is there are several advanced options so you can tune the software more to how your face moves to make it look more natural, not that it looks bad in default.  You will need at least a decent webcam for this to work and you need good lighting because shadows on your eyes may make your avatar blink rapidly.

One downside for me is that the software, probably because of my lighting, seems to think my mustache is part of my mouth which has hilarious results.  Also, if you wear glasses, beware of screen glare because that will make your avatar's eyes twitch too, but none of it's bad enough to ruin the fun you'll have with this software.

The software itself is very intuitive and the GUI is very easy to learn quickly and use like a pro, though there are some tedious details if you want to do a lot of facial customizing so the game is more uniform to your actual face.  Also, yes, you have to sit with your webcam directly on your face and keep it there, so if you are animated and make a lot of gestures be aware it would mess with the face-tracking.

Definitely recommend it to anyone who uses Skype Calls or Google Hangouts or Twitch or anything like that, it's a lot of fun and the big list of avatars you can use will keep you and your friends entertained for a while.  At this point I don't think they have voice modulation implemented but I am under the impression that voice modulation will be part of this program later on.

7/10 (possible 8/10 when the full version releases)

The only downside is the easyness of having to reset the webcam after moving your head a bit far out of the area. My only other issue with the software is that it doesnt let me select my microphone, forcing me to use my webcam's audio capability.

When intergrated with obs the software seems to slip in pretty easily, although I reccomend using your own audio for the time being, while editing the delay in FaceRig.

All in all, I definately reccomending using this program atleast once to try it out, it is pretty decent for only being in beta, so for the clunks that are present in it, they can be assumed to be gotten rid of once this program leaves beta.

this program is great. it takes input from your webcam and microphone and animates an avatar for you. there is a wide choice os avatars, and they are customisable themselves, and range from humans to demons to anime characters to animals to food. at the click of a button, you can broadcast the avatar to video-sharing programs like skype or twitch, which is ideal if your room is messy. the many backgrounds there are to choose from are all beautiful, and it is possible to set your own.

so far, it's still in beta version, and hopes to be in full release by about December 2014. from how often updates are applied and the current wide variety, i would see this as becoming an extremely widely used program, especially if it gets graphical optimisations, as I have heard rumours that it can chew memory.

the most important piece of information about this software, however, is to READ THE MANUAL. this very important document outlines how to do such potentially frustrating tasks as sending video to skype, or setting custom backgrounds (hint, they have to be placed in a specific folder)

Pretty incredible. 

With a Microsoft LifeCam HD 5000 the tracking at 3 feet was almost perfect. The only issues I saw were with a lazy eye glitch that popped up when looking up and to the left, and while adding props to some characters a runtime error would pop up. It wouldn't force the program to close, however the prop you chose would not appear.

As long as you are mindful of your facial expressions while using this, and can take some time to get used to the calibrations, you can have a blast!

Went ahead and bought it with all of the DLC, and for it being Beta, I'm not in the least bit disappointed. I saw all the promotions (especially from their indiegogo campaign) and could completely see the potential behind this software, and needless to say, I'm really excited about it. On the Beta, the facial tracking is a little off on "hard-to-read" angles and expressions, but a lot more stable and easy to work with (including recognition and speech tracking) than I would have expected. Again, this is only the Beta and there is still a lot more content and updates to come to improve the stability and over-all performance of this software.

In a nutshell, fantastic purchase. I won't and don't regret a single cent of it.

Great job guys, keep up the great work!

The program itself runs great! Facetracking is actually very reliable and responsive. Exceeded my expectations! Absolutely a nice toy for that price.
My only drawbacks came from the laptop-integrated webcam itself: Low framerate, screen reflecting in my glasses and covering my eyes, making it impossible for the tracking software to follow them.
Absolutely not facerig's fault, but you may wanna make sure to have a sensible camera installed before attempting to use it for advanced facetracking. A lot depends on the lighting conditions around you, too.

P.S., because it took me and friends of mine hours to figure out: restart skype before using it there. Like the manual actually says. Duh!
very good!

Firstly, it ran without any problems on my HP laptop. All I needed was to turn the webcam on (built in, thankfully) and follow the on-screen instructions for calibration. Very easy to set up and begin using straight away on Skype, although I haven't yet figured out how to get it to work on Chrome. 

I love the customisation, the accurate face tracking and detail in these avatars. Although you can't move their arms (yet?), you can still change the sensitivity to give your character a more fluid feel. Your character feels alive, which is amazing to see.

I'm thrilled with this purchace and believe the price is very generous for what the software offers.
